[An explosion of technological advancement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_Industrial_Revolution "Second Industrial Revolution") accompanied by the exploitation of cheap immigrant labor[[131]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-148) led to [rapid economic expansion during the late 19th and early 20th centuries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gilded_Age "Gilded Age"), allowing the United States to outpace the economies of England, France, and Germany combined.[[132]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-149)[[133]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-150) This fostered the amassing of power by [a few prominent industrialists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robber_baron_(industrialist) "Robber baron (industrialist)"), largely by their formation of [trusts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trust_(business) "Trust (business)") and [monopolies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monopoly "Monopoly") to prevent competition.[[134]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Atlantic2-151)[Tycoons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tycoon "Tycoon") led the nation's expansion in the [railroad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_rail_transportation_in_the_United_States "History of rail transportation in the United States"), [petroleum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_petroleum_industry_in_the_United_States "History of the petroleum industry in the United States"), and [steel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_steel_industry_(1850%E2%80%931970) "History of the steel industry (1850â€“1970)") industries. The United States emerged as a pioneer of the [automotive industry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_the_United_States "Automotive industry in the United States").[[135]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-152) These changes resulted in significant increases in [economic inequality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_inequality "Economic inequality"), [slum conditions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/How_the_Other_Half_Lives "How the Other Half Lives"), and [social unrest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_incidents_of_civil_unrest_in_the_United_States "List of incidents of civil unrest in the United States"), creating the environment for [labor unions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labor_history_of_the_United_States "Labor history of the United States") and [socialist movements](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_socialist_movement_in_the_United_States "History of the socialist movement in the United States") to begin to flourish.[[136]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-153)[[137]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-154)[[138]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Fraser2-155) This period eventually ended with the advent of the [Progressive Era](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Progressive_Era "Progressive Era"), which was characterized by significant reforms.[[139]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Aldrich2-156)[[140]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-157)

Pro-American elements in Hawaii [overthrew the Hawaiian monarchy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Overthrow_of_the_Hawaiian_Kingdom "Overthrow of the Hawaiian Kingdom"); the islands [were annexed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newlands_Resolution "Newlands Resolution") in 1898. That same year, [Puerto Rico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puerto_Rico "Puerto Rico"), [the Philippines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Philippines "The Philippines"), and [Guam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guam "Guam") were ceded to the U.S. by Spain after the latter's defeat in the [Spanishâ€“American War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93American_War "Spanishâ€“American War"). (The Philippines was granted full independence from the U.S. on July 4, 1946, following World War II. Puerto Rico and Guam have remained U.S. territories.)[[141]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-158)[American Samoa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Samoa "American Samoa") was acquired by the United States in 1900 after the [Second Samoan Civil War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_Samoan_Civil_War "Second Samoan Civil War").[[142]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-159) The [U.S. Virgin Islands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Virgin_Islands "United States Virgin Islands") were purchased from [Denmark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denmark "Denmark") in 1917.[[143]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-160)

triples.sentence: An [Edison Studios](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edison_Studios "Edison Studios") film showing immigrants arriving at [Ellis Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ellis_Island "Ellis Island") in [New York Harbor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Harbor "New York Harbor"), a major point of entry for European [immigrants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Immigration_to_the_United_States "Immigration to the United States") in the late 19th and early 20th centuries[[109]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-PriceBenton-Short2008-126)[[110]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-127)
triples.statement: An Edison Studios film shows immigrants arriving at Ellis Island in New York Harbor, which was a major point of entry for European immigrants in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

triples.sentence: Efforts toward [reconstruction in the secessionist South](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reconstruction_era "Reconstruction era") had begun as early as 1862,[[111]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDubois1935163-128) but it was only after [President Lincoln's assassination](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_Abraham_Lincoln "Assassination of Abraham Lincoln") that the three [Reconstruction Amendments](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reconstruction_Amendments "Reconstruction Amendments") to the Constitution were ratified [to protect civil rights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_rights_movement_(1865%E2%80%931896) "Civil rights movement (1865â€“1896)").
triples.statement: Reconstruction efforts in the secessionist South started as early as 1862, but the three Reconstruction Amendments to protect civil rights were ratified only after President Lincoln's assassination.

triples.sentence: The amendments codified nationally the abolition of slavery and involuntary servitude except as punishment for crimes, promised equal protection under the law for all persons, and prohibited discrimination on the basis of race or previous enslavement.[[112]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-129)[[113]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFoner198866-7,_251-261,_446-449-130)[[114]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-131)
triples.statement: The amendments nationally codified the abolition of slavery (except as punishment for crimes), guaranteed equal protection under the law, and forbade discrimination based on race or previous enslavement.

triples.sentence: As a result, African Americans took an active political role in ex-Confederate states in the decade following the Civil War.[[115]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFoner1988xxv-132)[[116]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDubois1935381-727-133)
triples.statement: As a result, African Americans became politically active in former Confederate states in the decade after the Civil War.

triples.sentence: This was accelerated by the [Homestead Acts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homestead_Acts "Homestead Acts"), through which nearly 10 percent of the total land area of the United States was given away free to some 1.6 million homesteaders.[[119]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Black2011kj2-136)[[120]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-137)
triples.statement: The Homestead Acts accelerated this growth by giving away nearly 10 percent of the total U.S. land area for free to approximately 1.6 million homesteaders.

triples.sentence: From 1865 through 1917, an unprecedented stream of [immigrants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Immigrants "Immigrants") arrived in the United States, including 24.4 million from Europe.[[121]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-138)
triples.statement: Between 1865 and 1917, a large wave of immigrants arrived in the United States, including 24.4 million from Europe.

triples.sentence: At the same time, about one million [French Canadians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French-Canadian_Americans "French-Canadian Americans") migrated from [Quebec](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quebec "Quebec") to [New England](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_England "New England").[[122]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-139)
triples.statement: Concurrently, about one million French Canadians migrated from Quebec to New England.

triples.sentence: The [Compromise of 1877](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compromise_of_1877 "Compromise of 1877") is generally considered the end of the Reconstruction era, as it resolved the electoral crisis following the [1876 presidential election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1876_United_States_presidential_election "1876 United States presidential election") and led President [Rutherford B. Hayes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rutherford_B._Hayes "Rutherford B. Hayes") to reduce the role of federal troops in the South.[[125]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFoner1988xxvii,_575-587-142)
triples.statement: The Compromise of 1877 is widely seen as the end of the Reconstruction era because it settled the 1876 presidential election crisis and prompted President Rutherford B. Hayes to lessen the presence of federal troops in the South.

triples.sentence: Immediately, the [Redeemers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redeemers "Redeemers") began evicting the [Carpetbaggers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carpetbaggers "Carpetbaggers") and quickly regained local control of Southern politics in the name of [white supremacy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_supremacy "White supremacy").[[126]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-143)[[127]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-144)
triples.statement: Immediately, the Redeemers started evicting Carpetbaggers and swiftly re-established local control over Southern politics in the name of white supremacy.

triples.sentence: African Americans endured a period of heightened, overt racism following Reconstruction, a time often considered the [nadir of American race relations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nadir_of_American_race_relations "Nadir of American race relations").[[128]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-ReferenceA2-145)[[129]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-146)
triples.statement: Following Reconstruction, African Americans faced a period of increased, overt racism, often regarded as the nadir of American race relations.

triples.sentence: A series of Supreme Court decisions, including _[Plessy v. Ferguson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plessy\_v.\_Ferguson "Plessy v. Ferguson")_, emptied the [Fourteenth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fourteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution") and [Fifteenth Amendments](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fifteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "Fifteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution") of their force, allowing [Jim Crow laws](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Crow_laws "Jim Crow laws") in the South to remain unchecked, [sundown towns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sundown_town "Sundown town") in the Midwest, and [segregation in communities across the country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racial_segregation_in_the_United_States "Racial segregation in the United States"), which would be reinforced in part by the policy of [redlining](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlining "Redlining") later adopted by the federal [Home Owners' Loan Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Home_Owners%27_Loan_Corporation "Home Owners' Loan Corporation").[[130]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-147)
triples.statement: Supreme Court decisions like Plessy v. Ferguson weakened the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Amendments, permitting unchecked Jim Crow laws in the South, sundown towns in the Midwest, and nationwide segregation, which was later reinforced by the federal policy of redlining.

triples.sentence: [An explosion of technological advancement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_Industrial_Revolution "Second Industrial Revolution") accompanied by the exploitation of cheap immigrant labor[[131]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-148) led to [rapid economic expansion during the late 19th and early 20th centuries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gilded_Age "Gilded Age"), allowing the United States to outpace the economies of England, France, and Germany combined.[[132]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-149)[[133]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-150)
triples.statement: A surge in technological advancement, along with the exploitation of cheap immigrant labor, resulted in rapid economic expansion in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, enabling the U.S. to surpass the combined economies of England, France, and Germany.

triples.sentence: This fostered the amassing of power by [a few prominent industrialists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robber_baron_(industrialist) "Robber baron (industrialist)"), largely by their formation of [trusts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trust_(business) "Trust (business)") and [monopolies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monopoly "Monopoly") to prevent competition.[[134]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Atlantic2-151)
triples.statement: This environment enabled a few prominent industrialists to accumulate power, primarily by creating trusts and monopolies to eliminate competition.

triples.sentence: These changes resulted in significant increases in [economic inequality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_inequality "Economic inequality"), [slum conditions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/How_the_Other_Half_Lives "How the Other Half Lives"), and [social unrest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_incidents_of_civil_unrest_in_the_United_States "List of incidents of civil unrest in the United States"), creating the environment for [labor unions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labor_history_of_the_United_States "Labor history of the United States") and [socialist movements](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_socialist_movement_in_the_United_States "History of the socialist movement in the United States") to begin to flourish.[[136]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-153)[[137]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-154)[[138]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Fraser2-155)
triples.statement: These changes led to major increases in economic inequality, slum conditions, and social unrest, which created conditions for labor unions and socialist movements to grow.

triples.sentence: This period eventually ended with the advent of the [Progressive Era](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Progressive_Era "Progressive Era"), which was characterized by significant reforms.[[139]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Aldrich2-156)[[140]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-157)
triples.statement: This period concluded with the beginning of the Progressive Era, which was defined by significant reforms.

triples.sentence: [American Samoa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Samoa "American Samoa") was acquired by the United States in 1900 after the [Second Samoan Civil War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_Samoan_Civil_War "Second Samoan Civil War").[[142]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-159)
triples.statement: The United States acquired American Samoa in 1900 after the Second Samoan Civil War.

section_path: World War I, Great Depression, and World War II (1917â€“1945)
section_body:
Main article: [History of the United States (1917â€“1945)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_(1917%E2%80%931945) "History of the United States (1917â€“1945)")

[![Image 32](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Trinity_shot_color_%284x3_cropped%29.jpg/250px-Trinity_shot_color_%284x3_cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Trinity_shot_color_(4x3_cropped).jpg)

The 1945 American [Trinity test](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trinity_(nuclear_test) "Trinity (nuclear test)"), the first-ever detonation of a [nuclear weapon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_weapon "Nuclear weapon")

The United States [entered World War I](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_entry_into_World_War_I "American entry into World War I") alongside the [Allies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I "Allies of World War I") in 1917 helping to turn the tide against the [Central Powers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Powers "Central Powers").[[144]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-161) In 1920, [a constitutional amendment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nineteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution") granted nationwide [women's suffrage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Women%27s_suffrage_in_the_United_States "Women's suffrage in the United States").[[145]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-162) During the 1920s and 1930s, radio for [mass communication](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_communication "Mass communication") and early television transformed communications nationwide.[[146]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWinchester2013410%E2%80%93411-163) The [Wall Street Crash of 1929](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wall_Street_Crash_of_1929 "Wall Street Crash of 1929") triggered the [Great Depression](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Depression_in_the_United_States "Great Depression in the United States"), to which President [Franklin D. Roosevelt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin D. Roosevelt") responded with the [New Deal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Deal "New Deal") plan of "reform, recovery and relief", a series of unprecedented and sweeping [recovery programs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alphabet_agencies "Alphabet agencies") and [employment relief projects](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Works_Progress_Administration "Works Progress Administration") combined with [financial reforms and regulations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regulatory_economics "Regulatory economics").[[147]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-164)[[148]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-165)

[Initially neutral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_non-interventionism_before_entering_World_War_II "United States non-interventionism before entering World War II") during [World War II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_history_of_the_United_States_during_World_War_II "Military history of the United States during World War II"), the U.S. began [supplying war materiel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lend-Lease "Lend-Lease") to the [Allies of World War II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II "Allies of World War II") in March 1941 and [entered the war](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_entry_into_World_War_II "American entry into World War II") in December after [Japan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empire_of_Japan "Empire of Japan")'s [attack on Pearl Harbor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor "Attack on Pearl Harbor").[[149]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Pearl_Harbor2-166) Agreeing to a "[Europe first](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Europe_first "Europe first")" policy, the U.S. concentrated its wartime efforts on Japan's allies [Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fascist_Italy "Fascist Italy") and [Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany") until their final defeat in May 1945. The U.S. [developed the first nuclear weapons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manhattan_Project "Manhattan Project") and [used them against the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atomic_bombings_of_Hiroshima_and_Nagasaki "Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki") in August 1945, ending the war.[[150]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-167)[[151]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-168) The United States was one of the "[Four Policemen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four_Policemen "Four Policemen")" who met to plan the [post-war world](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aftermath_of_World_War_II "Aftermath of World War II"), alongside the [United Kingdom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom"), the [Soviet Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union"), and [China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republic_of_China_(1912%E2%80%931949) "Republic of China (1912â€“1949)").[[152]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoopesBrinkley1997100-169)[[153]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGaddis197225-170) The U.S. emerged relatively unscathed from the war, with even greater [economic power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_power "Economic power") and [international political influence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sphere_of_influence "Sphere of influence").[[154]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-171)

triples.sentence: The United States [entered World War I](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_entry_into_World_War_I "American entry into World War I") alongside the [Allies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I "Allies of World War I") in 1917 helping to turn the tide against the [Central Powers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Powers "Central Powers").[[144]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-161)
triples.statement: In 1917, the United States entered World War I alongside the Allies, helping to turn the tide against the Central Powers.

triples.sentence: During the 1920s and 1930s, radio for [mass communication](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_communication "Mass communication") and early television transformed communications nationwide.[[146]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWinchester2013410%E2%80%93411-163)
triples.statement: During the 1920s and 1930s, radio and early television transformed communications nationwide.

triples.sentence: The [Wall Street Crash of 1929](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wall_Street_Crash_of_1929 "Wall Street Crash of 1929") triggered the [Great Depression](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Depression_in_the_United_States "Great Depression in the United States"), to which President [Franklin D. Roosevelt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin D. Roosevelt") responded with the [New Deal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Deal "New Deal") plan of "reform, recovery and relief", a series of unprecedented and sweeping [recovery programs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alphabet_agencies "Alphabet agencies") and [employment relief projects](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Works_Progress_Administration "Works Progress Administration") combined with [financial reforms and regulations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regulatory_economics "Regulatory economics").[[147]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-164)[[148]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-165)
triples.statement: The Wall Street Crash of 1929 triggered the Great Depression, to which President Franklin D. Roosevelt responded with the New Deal plan, a series of recovery programs, relief projects, and financial reforms.

triples.sentence: [Initially neutral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_non-interventionism_before_entering_World_War_II "United States non-interventionism before entering World War II") during [World War II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_history_of_the_United_States_during_World_War_II "Military history of the United States during World War II"), the U.S. began [supplying war materiel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lend-Lease "Lend-Lease") to the [Allies of World War II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II "Allies of World War II") in March 1941 and [entered the war](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_entry_into_World_War_II "American entry into World War II") in December after [Japan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empire_of_Japan "Empire of Japan")'s [attack on Pearl Harbor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor "Attack on Pearl Harbor").[[149]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Pearl_Harbor2-166)
triples.statement: Initially neutral during World War II, the U.S. began supplying war materiel to the Allies in March 1941 and entered the war in December after Japan's attack on Pearl Harbor.

triples.sentence: The U.S. [developed the first nuclear weapons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manhattan_Project "Manhattan Project") and [used them against the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atomic_bombings_of_Hiroshima_and_Nagasaki "Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki") in August 1945, ending the war.[[150]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-167)[[151]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-168)
triples.statement: The U.S. developed the first nuclear weapons and used them against the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in August 1945, ending the war.

triples.sentence: The United States was one of the "[Four Policemen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four_Policemen "Four Policemen")" who met to plan the [post-war world](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aftermath_of_World_War_II "Aftermath of World War II"), alongside the [United Kingdom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom"), the [Soviet Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union"), and [China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republic_of_China_(1912%E2%80%931949) "Republic of China (1912â€“1949)").[[152]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoopesBrinkley1997100-169)[[153]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGaddis197225-170)
triples.statement: The United States, along with the United Kingdom, the Soviet Union, and China, was one of the "Four Policemen" who met to plan the post-war world.

triples.sentence: The U.S. emerged relatively unscathed from the war, with even greater [economic power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_power "Economic power") and [international political influence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sphere_of_influence "Sphere of influence").[[154]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-171)
triples.statement: The U.S. emerged from the war relatively unscathed, with greater economic power and international political influence.

section_body:
Main articles: [History of the United States (1945â€“1964)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_(1945%E2%80%931964) "History of the United States (1945â€“1964)"), [History of the United States (1964â€“1980)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_(1964%E2%80%931980) "History of the United States (1964â€“1980)"), and [History of the United States (1980â€“1991)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_(1980%E2%80%931991) "History of the United States (1980â€“1991)")

[![Image 33](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Civil_Rights_March_on_Washington%2C_D.C._%28Leaders_marching_from_the_Washington_Monument_to_the_Lincoln_Memorial%29_-_NARA_-_542010.jpg/250px-Civil_Rights_March_on_Washington%2C_D.C._%28Leaders_marching_from_the_Washington_Monument_to_the_Lincoln_Memorial%29_-_NARA_-_542010.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Civil_Rights_March_on_Washington,_D.C._(Leaders_marching_from_the_Washington_Monument_to_the_Lincoln_Memorial)_-_NARA_-_542010.jpg)

Civil rights activists during the [March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/March_on_Washington_for_Jobs_and_Freedom "March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom") in [Washington, D.C.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C.") in August 1963

The end of [World War II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") in 1945 left the U.S. and the [Soviet Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union") as [superpowers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superpower "Superpower"), each with its own political, military, and economic [sphere of influence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sphere_of_influence "Sphere of influence"). Geopolitical tensions between the two superpowers soon led to the [Cold War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War").[[155]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Blakemore-20192-172)[[156]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-173)[[157]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-174) The U.S. implemented a policy of [containment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Containment "Containment") intended to limit the Soviet Union's sphere of influence; engaged in [regime change against governments perceived to be aligned with the Soviets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_involvement_in_regime_change#1945%E2%80%931991:_Cold_War "United States involvement in regime change"); and prevailed in the [Space Race](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Race "Space Race"), which culminated with the [first crewed Moon landing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apollo_11 "Apollo 11") in 1969.[[158]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-175)[[159]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Proxy2-176)

Domestically, the U.S. [experienced economic growth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post%E2%80%93World_War_II_economic_expansion "Postâ€“World War II economic expansion"), [urbanization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urbanization_in_the_United_States "Urbanization in the United States"), and [population growth following World War II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mid-20th_century_baby_boom "Mid-20th century baby boom").[[160]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWinchester2013305%E2%80%93308-177) The [civil rights movement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_rights_movement "Civil rights movement") emerged, with [Martin Luther King Jr.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr. "Martin Luther King Jr.") becoming a prominent leader in the early 1960s.[[161]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-178) The [Great Society](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Society "Great Society") plan of President [Lyndon B. Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson "Lyndon B. Johnson")'s administration resulted in groundbreaking and broad-reaching laws, policies and [a constitutional amendment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twenty-fourth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "Twenty-fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution") to counteract some of the worst effects of lingering [institutional racism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Institutional_racism "Institutional racism").[[162]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-179)

The [counterculture movement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Counterculture_of_the_1960s "Counterculture of the 1960s") in the U.S. brought significant social changes, including the liberalization of attitudes toward [recreational drug use](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recreational_drug_use "Recreational drug use") and [sexuality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexual_revolution "Sexual revolution").[[163]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-180)[[164]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-181) It also encouraged [open defiance of the military draft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Draft_evasion_in_the_Vietnam_War "Draft evasion in the Vietnam War") (leading to the [end of conscription](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conscription_in_the_United_States "Conscription in the United States") in 1973)[[165]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-182) and [wide opposition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opposition_to_United_States_involvement_in_the_Vietnam_War "Opposition to United States involvement in the Vietnam War") to [U.S. intervention in Vietnam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_in_the_Vietnam_War "United States in the Vietnam War"), with the U.S. totally withdrawing in 1975.[[166]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-183)[A societal shift in the roles of women](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Women%27s_liberation_movement_in_the_United_States "Women's liberation movement in the United States") was significantly responsible for the large increase in female paid labor participation starting in the 1970s, and by 1985 the majority of American women aged 16 and older were employed.[[167]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-184)

The [Fall of Communism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Revolutions_of_1989 "Revolutions of 1989") and the [dissolution of the Soviet Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union "Dissolution of the Soviet Union") from 1989 to 1991 marked the [end of the Cold War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/End_of_the_Cold_War "End of the Cold War") and [left the United States as the world's sole superpower](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superpower#After_the_Cold_War "Superpower").[[168]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Gaidar2-185)[[169]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-186)[[170]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-187)[[171]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-188) This cemented the United States' global influence, reinforcing the concept of the "[American Century](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Century "American Century")" as the U.S. dominated international political, cultural, economic, and military affairs.[[172]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-189)[[173]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-190)

triples.sentence: Geopolitical tensions between the two superpowers soon led to the [Cold War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War").[[155]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Blakemore-20192-172)[[156]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-173)[[157]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-174)
triples.statement: Geopolitical tensions between the two superpowers soon led to the Cold War.

triples.sentence: The U.S. implemented a policy of [containment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Containment "Containment") intended to limit the Soviet Union's sphere of influence; engaged in [regime change against governments perceived to be aligned with the Soviets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_involvement_in_regime_change#1945%E2%80%931991:_Cold_War "United States involvement in regime change"); and prevailed in the [Space Race](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Race "Space Race"), which culminated with the [first crewed Moon landing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apollo_11 "Apollo 11") in 1969.[[158]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-175)[[159]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Proxy2-176)
triples.statement: The U.S. implemented a containment policy to limit the Soviet Union's influence, engaged in regime change against governments seen as Soviet-aligned, and won the Space Race, which concluded with the first crewed Moon landing in 1969.

triples.sentence: Domestically, the U.S. [experienced economic growth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post%E2%80%93World_War_II_economic_expansion "Postâ€“World War II economic expansion"), [urbanization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urbanization_in_the_United_States "Urbanization in the United States"), and [population growth following World War II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mid-20th_century_baby_boom "Mid-20th century baby boom").[[160]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWinchester2013305%E2%80%93308-177)
triples.statement: Domestically, the U.S. experienced economic growth, urbanization, and population growth after World War II.

triples.sentence: The [Great Society](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Society "Great Society") plan of President [Lyndon B. Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson "Lyndon B. Johnson")'s administration resulted in groundbreaking and broad-reaching laws, policies and [a constitutional amendment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twenty-fourth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "Twenty-fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution") to counteract some of the worst effects of lingering [institutional racism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Institutional_racism "Institutional racism").[[162]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-179)
triples.statement: President Lyndon B. Johnson's Great Society plan resulted in significant laws, policies, and a constitutional amendment to combat the effects of institutional racism.

triples.sentence: The [counterculture movement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Counterculture_of_the_1960s "Counterculture of the 1960s") in the U.S. brought significant social changes, including the liberalization of attitudes toward [recreational drug use](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recreational_drug_use "Recreational drug use") and [sexuality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexual_revolution "Sexual revolution").[[163]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-180)[[164]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-181)
triples.statement: The counterculture movement in the U.S. led to significant social changes, including more liberal attitudes toward recreational drug use and sexuality.

triples.sentence: The [Fall of Communism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Revolutions_of_1989 "Revolutions of 1989") and the [dissolution of the Soviet Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union "Dissolution of the Soviet Union") from 1989 to 1991 marked the [end of the Cold War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/End_of_the_Cold_War "End of the Cold War") and [left the United States as the world's sole superpower](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superpower#After_the_Cold_War "Superpower").[[168]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Gaidar2-185)[[169]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-186)[[170]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-187)[[171]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-188)
triples.statement: The Fall of Communism and the dissolution of the Soviet Union from 1989 to 1991 marked the end of the Cold War and left the United States as the world's sole superpower.

section_body:
Main articles: [History of the United States (1991â€“2016)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_(1991%E2%80%932016) "History of the United States (1991â€“2016)") and [History of the United States (2016â€“present)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_(2016%E2%80%93present) "History of the United States (2016â€“present)")

[![Image 34](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/WTC_smoking_on_9-11.jpeg/250px-WTC_smoking_on_9-11.jpeg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:WTC_smoking_on_9-11.jpeg)

The [Twin Towers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Trade_Center_(1973%E2%80%932001) "World Trade Center (1973â€“2001)") in New York City during the [September 11 attacks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/September_11_attacks "September 11 attacks") of 2001

The 1990s saw the [longest recorded economic expansion in American history](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1990s_United_States_boom "1990s United States boom"), a dramatic [decline in U.S. crime rates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crime_in_the_United_States#Crime_over_time "Crime in the United States"), and [advances in technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_and_industrial_history_of_the_United_States#Computers_and_information_networks "Technological and industrial history of the United States"). Throughout this decade, technological innovations such as the [World Wide Web](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web "World Wide Web"), the evolution of the [Pentium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pentium_(original) "Pentium (original)") microprocessor in accordance with [Moore's law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moore%27s_law "Moore's law"), rechargeable [lithium-ion batteries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lithium-ion_battery "Lithium-ion battery"), the first [gene therapy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene_therapy "Gene therapy") trial, and [cloning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloning "Cloning") either emerged in the U.S. or were improved upon there. The [Human Genome Project](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_Genome_Project "Human Genome Project") was formally launched in 1990, while [Nasdaq](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nasdaq "Nasdaq") became the first stock market in the United States to trade online in 1998.[[174]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-191)

In the [Gulf War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulf_War "Gulf War") of 1991, [an American-led international coalition of states](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coalition_of_the_Gulf_War "Coalition of the Gulf War") expelled an [Iraqi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ba%27athist_Iraq "Ba'athist Iraq") invasion force that had occupied neighboring [Kuwait](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kuwait "Kuwait").[[175]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-192) The [September 11 attacks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/September_11_attacks "September 11 attacks") on the United States in 2001 by the [pan-Islamist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pan-Islamism "Pan-Islamism") militant organization [al-Qaeda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al-Qaeda "Al-Qaeda") led to the [war on terror](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_on_terror "War on terror") and subsequent [military interventions in Afghanistan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%932021) "War in Afghanistan (2001â€“2021)") and [in Iraq](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iraq_War "Iraq War").[[176]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-193)[[177]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-194)

The [U.S. housing bubble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2000s_United_States_housing_bubble "2000s United States housing bubble") culminated in 2007 with the [Great Recession](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Recession "Great Recession"), the largest economic contraction since the Great Depression.[[178]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-195) In the 2010s and early 2020s, the United States has experienced increased [political polarization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization_in_the_United_States "Political polarization in the United States") and [democratic backsliding](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_backsliding_in_the_United_States "Democratic backsliding in the United States").[[179]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-196)[[180]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-197)[[181]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-198)[[182]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-199) The country's polarization was violently reflected in the [January 2021 Capitol attack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/January_6_United_States_Capitol_attack "January 6 United States Capitol attack"),[[183]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Kleinfeld-2023-200) when a mob of insurrectionists[[184]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Pape-2022-201) entered the [U.S. Capitol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Capitol "United States Capitol") and sought to prevent the peaceful transfer of power[[185]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-202) in an [attempted self-coup d'Ã©tat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-coup#Notable_events_described_as_attempted_self-coups "Self-coup").[[186]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Multiple_Sources-203)

triples.sentence: In the [Gulf War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulf_War "Gulf War") of 1991, [an American-led international coalition of states](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coalition_of_the_Gulf_War "Coalition of the Gulf War") expelled an [Iraqi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ba%27athist_Iraq "Ba'athist Iraq") invasion force that had occupied neighboring [Kuwait](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kuwait "Kuwait").[[175]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-192)
triples.statement: During the 1991 Gulf War, a U.S.-led international coalition expelled an Iraqi invasion force from Kuwait.

triples.sentence: The country's polarization was violently reflected in the [January 2021 Capitol attack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/January_6_United_States_Capitol_attack "January 6 United States Capitol attack"),[[183]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Kleinfeld-2023-200) when a mob of insurrectionists[[184]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Pape-2022-201) entered the [U.S. Capitol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Capitol "United States Capitol") and sought to prevent the peaceful transfer of power[[185]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-202) in an [attempted self-coup d'Ã©tat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-coup#Notable_events_described_as_attempted_self-coups "Self-coup").[[186]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Multiple_Sources-203)
triples.statement: The country's polarization was violently reflected in the January 2021 Capitol attack, where a mob of insurrectionists entered the U.S. Capitol to try to prevent the peaceful transfer of power in an attempted self-coup d'Ã©tat.

section_body:
Main article: [Geography of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geography_of_the_United_States "Geography of the United States")

[![Image 35](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Uspaintedrelief.png/250px-Uspaintedrelief.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Uspaintedrelief.png)

A [topographic map](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topographic_map "Topographic map") of the United States

The United States is the world's [third-largest country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area "List of countries and dependencies by area") by total area behind Russia and Canada.[[c]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-largestcountry-15) The 48 [contiguous states and the District of Columbia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contiguous_United_States "Contiguous United States") have a combined area of 3,119,885 square miles (8,080,470 km 2).[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-CensusGov2010HTML-14)[[187]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-204) In 2021, the United States had 8% of the Earth's permanent meadows and pastures and 10% of its cropland.[[188]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Food_and_Agriculture_Organization_of_the_United_Nations-2023-205)

Starting in the east, [the coastal plain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlantic_Plain "Atlantic Plain") of the [Atlantic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean") seaboard gives way to inland forests and rolling hills in the [Piedmont](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piedmont_(United_States) "Piedmont (United States)") plateau region.[[189]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-206) The [Appalachian Mountains](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Appalachian_Mountains "Appalachian Mountains") and the [Adirondack Massif](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adirondack_Mountains "Adirondack Mountains") separate the [East Coast](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Coast_of_the_United_States "East Coast of the United States") from the [Great Lakes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Lakes "Great Lakes") and the grasslands of [the Midwest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Midwestern_United_States "Midwestern United States").[[190]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-NAU-207) The [Mississippi River System](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mississippi_River_System "Mississippi River System"), the world's [fourth-longest river system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_rivers_by_length "List of rivers by length"), runs predominantly northâ€“south through the center of the country. The flat and fertile [prairie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prairie "Prairie") of the [Great Plains](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Plains "Great Plains") stretches to the west, interrupted by [a highland region](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Interior_Highlands "U.S. Interior Highlands") in the southeast.[[190]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-NAU-207)

[![Image 36](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Canyon_River_Tree_%28165872763%29.jpeg/250px-Canyon_River_Tree_%28165872763%29.jpeg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Canyon_River_Tree_(165872763).jpeg)

The [Grand Canyon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Canyon "Grand Canyon") in Arizona

The [Rocky Mountains](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rocky_Mountains "Rocky Mountains"), west of the Great Plains, extend north to south across the country, peaking at over 14,000 feet (4,300 m) in [Colorado](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colorado "Colorado").[[191]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-208) The [supervolcano](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supervolcano "Supervolcano") underlying [Yellowstone National Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yellowstone_National_Park "Yellowstone National Park") in the Rocky Mountains, the [Yellowstone Caldera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yellowstone_Caldera "Yellowstone Caldera"), is the continent's largest volcanic feature.[[192]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-209) Farther west are the rocky [Great Basin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Basin "Great Basin") and the [Chihuahuan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chihuahuan_Desert "Chihuahuan Desert"), [Sonoran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sonoran_Desert "Sonoran Desert"), and [Mojave](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mojave_Desert "Mojave Desert") deserts.[[193]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-210) In the northwest corner of [Arizona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arizona "Arizona"), carved by the [Colorado River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colorado_River "Colorado River"), is the [Grand Canyon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Canyon "Grand Canyon"), a steep-sided canyon and popular tourist destination[[194]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-211) known for its overwhelming visual size and intricate, colorful landscape. The [Cascade](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cascade_Range "Cascade Range") and [Sierra Nevada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sierra_Nevada "Sierra Nevada") mountain ranges run close to the [Pacific coast](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Coast_of_the_United_States "West Coast of the United States"). The [lowest and highest points in the contiguous United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extreme_points_of_the_United_States "Extreme points of the United States") are in the State of California,[[195]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-212) about 84 miles (135 km) apart.[[196]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-213)

At an elevation of 20,310 feet (6,190.5 m), Alaska's [Denali](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denali "Denali") (also called Mount McKinley) is the highest peak in the country and on the continent.[[197]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-214) Active [volcanoes in the U.S.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_volcanoes_in_the_United_States "List of volcanoes in the United States") are common throughout Alaska's [Alexander](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Archipelago "Alexander Archipelago") and [Aleutian Islands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleutian_Islands "Aleutian Islands"). Located entirely outside North America, the archipelago of Hawaii consists of volcanic islands, [physiographically](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physical_geography "Physical geography") and [ethnologically](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnology "Ethnology") part of the [Polynesian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polynesia "Polynesia") subregion of [Oceania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oceania "Oceania").[[198]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-215)

In addition to its total land area, the United States has one of the world's largest marine [exclusive economic zones](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exclusive_economic_zones "Exclusive economic zones") spanning approximately 4.5 million square miles (11.7 million km 2) of ocean.[[199]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-216)[[200]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-217)

triples.sentence: In 2021, the United States had 8% of the Earth's permanent meadows and pastures and 10% of its cropland.[[188]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Food_and_Agriculture_Organization_of_the_United_Nations-2023-205)
triples.statement: In 2021, the United States had 8% of the Earth's permanent meadows and pastures and 10% of its cropland.

triples.sentence: Starting in the east, [the coastal plain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlantic_Plain "Atlantic Plain") of the [Atlantic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean") seaboard gives way to inland forests and rolling hills in the [Piedmont](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piedmont_(United_States) "Piedmont (United States)") plateau region.[[189]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-206)
triples.statement: The coastal plain of the Atlantic seaboard gives way to inland forests and rolling hills in the Piedmont plateau region.

triples.sentence: The [supervolcano](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supervolcano "Supervolcano") underlying [Yellowstone National Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yellowstone_National_Park "Yellowstone National Park") in the Rocky Mountains, the [Yellowstone Caldera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yellowstone_Caldera "Yellowstone Caldera"), is the continent's largest volcanic feature.[[192]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-209)
triples.statement: The Yellowstone Caldera, the supervolcano underlying Yellowstone National Park in the Rocky Mountains, is the continent's largest volcanic feature.

triples.sentence: Farther west are the rocky [Great Basin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Basin "Great Basin") and the [Chihuahuan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chihuahuan_Desert "Chihuahuan Desert"), [Sonoran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sonoran_Desert "Sonoran Desert"), and [Mojave](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mojave_Desert "Mojave Desert") deserts.[[193]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-210)
triples.statement: Farther west are the rocky Great Basin and the Chihuahuan, Sonoran, and Mojave deserts.

triples.sentence: The [lowest and highest points in the contiguous United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extreme_points_of_the_United_States "Extreme points of the United States") are in the State of California,[[195]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-212) about 84 miles (135 km) apart.[[196]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-213)
triples.statement: The lowest and highest points in the contiguous United States are in the State of California, about 84 miles (135 km) apart.

section_body:
Main articles: [Fauna of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fauna_of_the_United_States "Fauna of the United States") and [Flora of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flora_of_the_United_States "Flora of the United States")

[![Image 38: A bald eagle](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Bald_eagle_about_to_fly_in_Alaska_%282016%29.jpg/250px-Bald_eagle_about_to_fly_in_Alaska_%282016%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Bald_eagle_about_to_fly_in_Alaska_(2016).jpg)

The [bald eagle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bald_eagle "Bald eagle"), the [national emblem of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bald_eagle#National_symbol_of_the_United_States "Bald eagle") since 1782 and officially declared the national bird in 2024[[212]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-229)

The U.S. is one of 17 [megadiverse countries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Megadiverse_countries "Megadiverse countries") containing large numbers of [endemic species](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_endangered_animals_of_North_America "List of endangered animals of North America"): about 17,000 species of [vascular plants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vascular_plant "Vascular plant") occur in the contiguous United States and Alaska, and over 1,800 species of [flowering plants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flowering_plant "Flowering plant") are found in Hawaii, few of which occur on the mainland.[[213]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-230) The United States is home to 428 [mammal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mammal "Mammal") species, 784 birds, 311 reptiles, 295 [amphibians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amphibian "Amphibian"),[[214]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Current_Results_#_of_native_species_in_the_US-231) and around 91,000 insect species.[[215]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-232)

There are [63 national parks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_the_United_States "List of national parks of the United States"), and [hundreds of other federally managed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_lands "Federal lands") monuments, forests, and [wilderness areas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Wilderness_Preservation_System "National Wilderness Preservation System"), administered by the [National Park Service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Park_Service "National Park Service") and other agencies.[[216]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-233) About 28% of the country's land is publicly owned and federally managed,[[217]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-NYTimes_Federal_Land-234) primarily in the [Western States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_United_States "Western United States").[[218]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-AKLeg_CRS_Federal_Land-235)[Most of this land is protected](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protected_areas_of_the_United_States "Protected areas of the United States"), though some is leased for commercial use, and less than one percent is used for military purposes.[[219]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Federal_Land_Ownership-236)[[220]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Fed_Land_Uses-237)

[Environmental issues in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_the_United_States "Environmental issues in the United States") include debates on [non-renewable resources](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-renewable_resource "Non-renewable resource") and [nuclear energy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_power_debate "Nuclear power debate"), [air and water pollution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pollution_prevention_in_the_US "Pollution prevention in the US"), [biodiversity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity "Biodiversity"), logging and [deforestation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deforestation_in_the_United_States "Deforestation in the United States"),[[221]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-238)[[222]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-239) and [climate change](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_change_in_the_United_States "Climate change in the United States").[[223]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-240)[[224]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-241) The [U.S. Environmental Protection Agency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Environmental_Protection_Agency "United States Environmental Protection Agency") (EPA) is the federal agency charged with [addressing most environmental-related issues](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_policy_of_the_United_States "Environmental policy of the United States").[[225]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Collin2006-242) The [idea of wilderness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Wilderness_Preservation_System "National Wilderness Preservation System") has shaped the management of public lands since 1964, with the [Wilderness Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilderness_Act "Wilderness Act").[[226]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-243) The [Endangered Species Act of 1973](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Endangered_Species_Act_of_1973 "Endangered Species Act of 1973") provides a way to protect threatened and endangered species and their habitats. The [United States Fish and Wildlife Service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Fish_and_Wildlife_Service "United States Fish and Wildlife Service") implements and enforces the Act.[[227]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Office-244) In 2024, the U.S. ranked 35th among 180 countries in the [Environmental Performance Index](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_Performance_Index "Environmental Performance Index").[[228]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-245)

triples.sentence: [Environmental issues in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_the_United_States "Environmental issues in the United States") include debates on [non-renewable resources](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-renewable_resource "Non-renewable resource") and [nuclear energy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_power_debate "Nuclear power debate"), [air and water pollution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pollution_prevention_in_the_US "Pollution prevention in the US"), [biodiversity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity "Biodiversity"), logging and [deforestation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deforestation_in_the_United_States "Deforestation in the United States"),[[221]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-238)[[222]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-239) and [climate change](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_change_in_the_United_States "Climate change in the United States").[[223]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-240)[[224]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-241)
triples.statement: Environmental issues in the United States include debates on non-renewable resources, nuclear energy, pollution, biodiversity, logging, deforestation, and climate change.

triples.sentence: The [idea of wilderness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Wilderness_Preservation_System "National Wilderness Preservation System") has shaped the management of public lands since 1964, with the [Wilderness Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilderness_Act "Wilderness Act").[[226]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-243)
triples.statement: The concept of wilderness, formalized by the Wilderness Act of 1964, has influenced the management of public lands.

triples.sentence: The [United States Fish and Wildlife Service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Fish_and_Wildlife_Service "United States Fish and Wildlife Service") implements and enforces the Act.[[227]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Office-244)
triples.statement: The United States Fish and Wildlife Service is responsible for implementing and enforcing the Endangered Species Act.

section_body:
Main article: [Politics of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Politics_of_the_United_States "Politics of the United States")

[![Image 39](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/United_States_Capitol_west_front_edit2.jpg/250px-United_States_Capitol_west_front_edit2.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:United_States_Capitol_west_front_edit2.jpg)

The [Capitol Building](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Capitol "United States Capitol"), seat of legislative government, houses both chambers of [Congress](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Congress "U.S. Congress").

[![Image 40](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/White_House_lawn_%28long_tightly_cropped%29.jpg/250px-White_House_lawn_%28long_tightly_cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:White_House_lawn_(long_tightly_cropped).jpg)

The [White House](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_House "White House"), residence and workplace of the president, includes offices for [the executive staff](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Executive_Office_of_the_President_of_the_United_States "Executive Office of the President of the United States").

[![Image 41](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Panorama_of_United_States_Supreme_Court_Building_at_Dusk.jpg/250px-Panorama_of_United_States_Supreme_Court_Building_at_Dusk.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Panorama_of_United_States_Supreme_Court_Building_at_Dusk.jpg)

The [Supreme Court Building](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Supreme_Court_Building "United States Supreme Court Building") houses the [nation's highest court](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States "Supreme Court of the United States").

The United States is a [federal republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_republic "Federal republic") of 50 [states](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._state "U.S. state") and a federal capital district, [Washington, D.C.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C.") The U.S. asserts sovereignty over five [unincorporated territories](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Territories_of_the_United_States "Territories of the United States") and [several uninhabited island possessions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Minor_Outlying_Islands "United States Minor Outlying Islands").[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-HRI-2012-28)[[229]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOnuf2010xvii-246) It is the world's oldest surviving federation,[[230]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-247) and its [presidential system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presidential_system "Presidential system") of national government has been adopted, in whole or in part, by many newly independent states worldwide following their [decolonization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decolonization "Decolonization").[[231]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-248) The [Constitution of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitution_of_the_United_States "Constitution of the United States") serves as [the country's supreme legal document](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supremacy_Clause "Supremacy Clause").[[232]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-249) Most scholars describe the United States as a [liberal democracy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liberal_democracy "Liberal democracy").[[233]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Scheb-250)[[r]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-262)

triples.sentence: The U.S. asserts sovereignty over five [unincorporated territories](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Territories_of_the_United_States "Territories of the United States") and [several uninhabited island possessions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Minor_Outlying_Islands "United States Minor Outlying Islands").[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-HRI-2012-28)[[229]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOnuf2010xvii-246)
triples.statement: The U.S. asserts sovereignty over five unincorporated territories and several uninhabited island possessions.

triples.sentence: It is the world's oldest surviving federation,[[230]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-247) and its [presidential system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presidential_system "Presidential system") of national government has been adopted, in whole or in part, by many newly independent states worldwide following their [decolonization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decolonization "Decolonization").[[231]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-248)
triples.statement: The United States is the world's oldest surviving federation, and its presidential system of government has been adopted to some extent by many newly independent states after their decolonization.

triples.sentence: Most scholars describe the United States as a [liberal democracy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liberal_democracy "Liberal democracy").[[233]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Scheb-250)[[r]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-262)
triples.statement: Most scholars describe the United States as a liberal democracy.

section_body:
Main article: [Federal government of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States "Federal government of the United States")

Composed of three branches, all headquartered in Washington, D.C., the federal government is the national government of the United States. The [U.S. Constitution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Constitution "U.S. Constitution") establishes a [separation of powers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_of_powers "Separation of powers") intended to provide a system of [checks and balances](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Checks_and_balances "Checks and balances") to prevent any of the three branches from becoming supreme.[[245]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-263)

*   The [U.S. Congress](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress") is a [bicameral legislature](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bicameral_legislature "Bicameral legislature") made up of the [Senate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Senate "United States Senate") and the [House of Representatives](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives "United States House of Representatives"). The Senate has 100 membersâ€”two residents from each state and elected by that state's voters for a six-year term. The House of Representatives has 435 members, elected for a two-year term by the constituency of the [congressional district](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_congressional_districts "List of United States congressional districts") where they reside. A [state's legislature](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_legislature_(United_States) "State legislature (United States)") decides the district boundaries, which are contiguous within the state. Every U.S. congressional district is of equivalent population and sends one representative to Congress.[[246]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-264) Election years for senators are staggered so that only one-third of them will be up for election every two years.[[247]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-265) U.S. representatives are all up for election at the same time every two years. The U.S. Congress makes [federal law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_law "Federal law"), [declares war](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Declaration_of_war "Declaration of war"), approves treaties, has the [power of the purse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_of_the_purse "Power of the purse"),[[248]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-266) and has [the power of impeachment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impeachment_in_the_United_States "Impeachment in the United States").[[249]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-267) One of its foremost non-legislative functions is [the power to investigate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Congressional_investigation "Congressional investigation") and oversee the executive branch.[[250]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-tws2010Sep11t11-268)[Congressional oversight](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Congressional_oversight "Congressional oversight") is usually delegated to committees and is facilitated by [Congress's power to issue subpoenas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contempt_of_Congress "Contempt of Congress").[[251]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-tws2010Sep11t13-269) Much of the work of Congress is performed by [a collection of committees](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_congressional_committee "United States congressional committee"), each appointed for a specific purpose or function. Committee membership is by tradition and statute [bipartisan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bipartisan "Bipartisan"), but all committees are [chaired](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chair_(officer) "Chair (officer)") by a member of the [majority party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Majority_party "Majority party"), who sets the committee agenda.[[252]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-270)

[![Image 42](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Official_Presidential_Portrait_of_President_Donald_J._Trump_%282025%29.jpg/250px-Official_Presidential_Portrait_of_President_Donald_J._Trump_%282025%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Official_Presidential_Portrait_of_President_Donald_J._Trump_(2025).jpg)

[Donald Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump")

[President](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United States")

[![Image 43](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/January_2025_Official_Vice_Presidential_Portrait_of_JD_Vance.jpg/250px-January_2025_Official_Vice_Presidential_Portrait_of_JD_Vance.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:January_2025_Official_Vice_Presidential_Portrait_of_JD_Vance.jpg)

[JD Vance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JD_Vance "JD Vance")

[Vice President](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States "Vice President of the United States")

*   The U.S. president is the [head of state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Head_of_state "Head of state"), [commander-in-chief](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commander-in-chief "Commander-in-chief") of the military, [chief executive of the federal government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Head_of_government "Head of government"), and has the ability to veto [legislative bills](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_(law) "Bill (law)") from the U.S. Congress before they become law. However, [presidential vetoes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Veto_power_in_the_United_States "Veto power in the United States") can be overridden by a two-thirds [supermajority](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supermajority#Use_in_governments_around_the_world "Supermajority") vote in both chambers of Congress. The president appoints the [members of the Cabinet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cabinet_of_the_United_States "Cabinet of the United States"), subject to Senate approval, and names other officials who administer and enforce federal law and policy through [their respective agencies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_federal_agencies_in_the_United_States "List of federal agencies in the United States").[[253]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-271) The president also has clemency power for federal crimes and [can issue pardons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_pardons_in_the_United_States "Federal pardons in the United States"). Finally, the president has the authority to issue expansive "[executive orders](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Executive_orders "Executive orders")" in a number of policy areas, subject to [judicial review](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Judicial_review_in_the_United_States "Judicial review in the United States"). Candidates for president campaign with a vice-presidential [running mate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Running_mate "Running mate"). Both candidates are elected together, or defeated together, in a presidential election. Unlike other votes in American politics, this is technically an [indirect election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indirect_election "Indirect election") in which the winner will be determined by the [U.S. Electoral College](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Electoral_College "United States Electoral College"). There, votes are officially cast by individual electors selected by [their state legislature](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_legislature_(United_States) "State legislature (United States)").[[254]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-272) In practice, however, each of the 50 states chooses a group of presidential electors who are required by state law to confirm the winner of their state's popular vote. Each state is allocated two electors plus one additional elector for every congressional district in the state, which in effect combines to equal the number of elected officials that state sends to Congress. The District of Columbia, with no representatives or senators, is allocated three electoral votes. Both the president and the vice president serve a four-year term, and the president may be [reelected to the office only once](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twenty-second_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "Twenty-second Amendment to the United States Constitution"), for one additional four-year term.[[s]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-273)
*   The [U.S. federal judiciary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_judiciary_of_the_United_States "Federal judiciary of the United States"), whose judges are all appointed for life by the president with Senate approval, consists primarily of the [U.S. Supreme Court](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States "Supreme Court of the United States"), the [U.S. courts of appeals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_courts_of_appeals "United States courts of appeals"), and the [U.S. district courts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_district_court "United States district court"). The lowest level in the federal judiciary is the federal district court, which decides all cases considered to be under "[original jurisdiction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Original_jurisdiction#Federal_and_state_courts "Original jurisdiction")", such as federal statutes, constitutional law, or [international treaties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_treaties "International treaties"). After a federal district court has decided a case, its decision may be contested and sent to a higher court, a federal court of appeals. The U.S. judicial system's 12 federal circuits divide the country into 12 separate geographic administrative regions for appeals decisions.
