The next and highest court in the system is the Supreme Court of the United States.[[255]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FedJud-274) The U.S. Supreme Court interprets laws and [overturns those it finds unconstitutional](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Judicial_review "Judicial review").[[255]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FedJud-274) On average, the Supreme Court receives about 7,000 appeals petitions for [writs of certiorari](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Writs_of_certiorari "Writs of certiorari") each year, but only grants about 80.[[256]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-275) Consisting of nine members led by the [Chief Justice of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_the_United_States "Chief Justice of the United States"), the court judges each case before it by majority decision. As with all other federal judges, the members are appointed for life by the sitting president with Senate approval when a vacancy becomes available.[[257]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-276)

The three-branch system is known as the [presidential system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presidential_system "Presidential system"), in contrast to the [parliamentary system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parliamentary_system "Parliamentary system") where the executive is part of the legislative body. Many countries around the world adopted this aspect of the 1789 Constitution of the United States, especially in the [postcolonial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Postcolonialism "Postcolonialism") Americas.[[258]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Sundquist-277)

triples.sentence: Election years for senators are staggered so that only one-third of them will be up for election every two years.[[247]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-265)
triples.statement: Senate elections are staggered, with one-third of senators being up for election every two years.

triples.sentence: Committee membership is by tradition and statute [bipartisan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bipartisan "Bipartisan"), but all committees are [chaired](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chair_(officer) "Chair (officer)") by a member of the [majority party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Majority_party "Majority party"), who sets the committee agenda.[[252]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-270)
triples.statement: While committee membership is traditionally bipartisan, the chair of each committee is a member of the majority party and sets the agenda.

triples.sentence: Many countries around the world adopted this aspect of the 1789 Constitution of the United States, especially in the [postcolonial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Postcolonialism "Postcolonialism") Americas.[[258]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Sundquist-277)
triples.statement: Many countries, particularly in postcolonial Americas, adopted the presidential system from the 1789 U.S. Constitution.

section_body:
Main article: [Political parties in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_parties_in_the_United_States "Political parties in the United States")

Further information: [List of political parties in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_the_United_States "List of political parties in the United States") and [Political party strength in U.S. states](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_party_strength_in_U.S._states "Political party strength in U.S. states")

[![Image 47](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/US_state_Legislature_and_Governor_Control.svg/250px-US_state_Legislature_and_Governor_Control.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:US_state_Legislature_and_Governor_Control.svg)

States and territories by partisan control, as of February 2025: 

[Democratic Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States) "Democratic Party (United States)")

[Republican Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States) "Republican Party (United States)")

[New Progressive Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Progressive_Party_(Puerto_Rico) "New Progressive Party (Puerto Rico)")

Divided partisan control

The Constitution is silent on political parties. However, they developed independently in the 18th century with the [Federalist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federalist_Party "Federalist Party") and [Anti-Federalist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-Federalist_Party "Anti-Federalist Party") parties.[[266]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Hofstadter-1969-iv-285) Since then, the United States has operated as a _de facto_[two-party system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-party_system "Two-party system"), though the parties have changed over time.[[267]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Blake-2021-286) Since the mid-19th century, the two main national parties have been the [Democratic Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States) "Democratic Party (United States)") and the [Republican Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States) "Republican Party (United States)"). The former is perceived as [relatively liberal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_liberalism_in_the_United_States "Modern liberalism in the United States") in [its political platform](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_positions_of_the_Democratic_Party_(United_States) "Political positions of the Democratic Party (United States)") while the latter is perceived as [relatively conservative](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservatism_in_the_United_States "Conservatism in the United States") in [its platform](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_positions_of_the_Republican_Party_(United_States) "Political positions of the Republican Party (United States)").[[268]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-287)

triples.sentence: However, they developed independently in the 18th century with the [Federalist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federalist_Party "Federalist Party") and [Anti-Federalist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-Federalist_Party "Anti-Federalist Party") parties.[[266]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Hofstadter-1969-iv-285)
triples.statement: Political parties, including the Federalist and Anti-Federalist parties, developed independently in the 18th century.

triples.sentence: Since then, the United States has operated as a _de facto_[two-party system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-party_system "Two-party system"), though the parties have changed over time.[[267]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Blake-2021-286)
triples.statement: The United States has since operated as a de facto two-party system, with the specific parties changing over time.

triples.sentence: The former is perceived as [relatively liberal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_liberalism_in_the_United_States "Modern liberalism in the United States") in [its political platform](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_positions_of_the_Democratic_Party_(United_States) "Political positions of the Democratic Party (United States)") while the latter is perceived as [relatively conservative](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservatism_in_the_United_States "Conservatism in the United States") in [its platform](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_positions_of_the_Republican_Party_(United_States) "Political positions of the Republican Party (United States)").[[268]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-287)
triples.statement: The Democratic Party is perceived as having a relatively liberal political platform, while the Republican Party is perceived as having a relatively conservative one.

section_body:
Main articles: [Foreign relations of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_the_United_States "Foreign relations of the United States") and [Foreign policy of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreign_policy_of_the_United_States "Foreign policy of the United States")

[![Image 48: see caption](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Midtown_Manhattan_Skyline_004_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-Midtown_Manhattan_Skyline_004_%28cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Midtown_Manhattan_Skyline_004_(cropped).jpg)

The [United Nations headquarters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Headquarters_of_the_United_Nations "Headquarters of the United Nations") has been situated along the [East River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_River "East River") in [Midtown Manhattan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Midtown_Manhattan "Midtown Manhattan") since 1952; in 1945, the United States was a [founding member of the UN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Founding_member_of_the_United_Nations "Founding member of the United Nations").

The United States has an established structure of foreign relations, with the world's [second-largest diplomatic corps](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_diplomatic_missions "List of countries by number of diplomatic missions") as of 2024[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=United_States&action=edit). It is a [permanent member of the United Nations Security Council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Permanent_members_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council "Permanent members of the United Nations Security Council")[[269]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-288) and home to the [United Nations headquarters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Headquarters_of_the_United_Nations "Headquarters of the United Nations").[[270]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-289) The United States is a member of the [G7](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G7 "G7"),[[271]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-290)[G20](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G20 "G20"),[[272]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-291) and [OECD](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OECD "OECD") intergovernmental organizations.[[273]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-292)[Almost all countries have embassies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_in_the_United_States "List of diplomatic missions in the United States") and many have [consulates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consul_(representative) "Consul (representative)") (official representatives) in the country. Likewise, nearly all countries host formal [diplomatic missions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diplomatic_mission "Diplomatic mission") with the United States, except [Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Iranâ€“United States relations"),[[274]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-293)[North Korea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Korea%E2%80%93United_States_relations "North Koreaâ€“United States relations"),[[275]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-294) and [Bhutan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Bhutan#Other_countries "Foreign relations of Bhutan").[[276]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-295) Though [Taiwan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taiwan%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Taiwanâ€“United States relations") does not have formal diplomatic relations with the U.S., it maintains close unofficial relations.[[277]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-296) The United States regularly [supplies Taiwan with military equipment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Six_Assurances "Six Assurances") to deter potential Chinese aggression.[[278]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-297) Its geopolitical attention also turned to the [Indo-Pacific](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-Pacific "Indo-Pacific") when the United States joined the [Quadrilateral Security Dialogue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadrilateral_Security_Dialogue "Quadrilateral Security Dialogue") with Australia, India, and Japan.[[279]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-kobara-298)

The United States has a "[Special Relationship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special_Relationship "Special Relationship")" [with the United Kingdom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom%E2%80%93United_States_relations "United Kingdomâ€“United States relations")[[280]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-299) and strong ties [with Canada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Canadaâ€“United States relations"),[[281]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-300)[Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Australiaâ€“United States relations"),[[282]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-301)[New Zealand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand%E2%80%93United_States_relations "New Zealandâ€“United States relations"),[[283]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-302)[the Philippines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philippines%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Philippinesâ€“United States relations"),[[284]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-303)[Japan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Japanâ€“United States relations"),[[285]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-304)[South Korea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Korea%E2%80%93United_States_relations "South Koreaâ€“United States relations"),[[286]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-305)[Israel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Israelâ€“United States relations"),[[287]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-306) and several [European Union countries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union "Member state of the European Union") such as [France](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/France%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Franceâ€“United States relations"), [Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italy%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Italyâ€“United States relations"), [Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Germany%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Germanyâ€“United States relations"), [Spain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spain%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Spainâ€“United States relations"), and [Poland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poland%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Polandâ€“United States relations").[[288]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-307) The U.S. works closely with its [NATO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NATO "NATO") allies on military and [national security](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_security "National security") issues, and with countries in the Americas through the [Organization of American States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organization_of_American_States "Organization of American States") and the [United Statesâ€“Mexicoâ€“Canada Free Trade Agreement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States%E2%80%93Mexico%E2%80%93Canada_Agreement "United Statesâ€“Mexicoâ€“Canada Agreement"). The U.S. exercises full international defense authority and responsibility for [Micronesia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federated_States_of_Micronesia "Federated States of Micronesia"), the [Marshall Islands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marshall_Islands "Marshall Islands"), and [Palau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palau "Palau") through the [Compact of Free Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compact_of_Free_Association "Compact of Free Association").[[255]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FedJud-274) It has increasingly conducted strategic cooperation [with India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Indiaâ€“United States relations"),[[289]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-308) while [its ties with China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Chinaâ€“United States relations") have steadily deteriorated.[[290]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-309)[[291]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-310)

Beginning in 2014, the U.S. had become [a key ally of Ukraine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ukraine%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Ukraineâ€“United States relations").[[292]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-311)[[293]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-312) After [Donald Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump") was elected U.S. president in 2024, he sought to negotiate an end to the [Russo-Ukrainian War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russo-Ukrainian_War "Russo-Ukrainian War"). He paused all military aid to Ukraine in March 2025,[[294]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-313) although the aid resumed later.[[295]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-314) Trump also ended U.S. intelligence sharing with the country,[[296]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-:5-315) but this too was eventually restored.[[297]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-316)

triples.sentence: It is a [permanent member of the United Nations Security Council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Permanent_members_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council "Permanent members of the United Nations Security Council")[[269]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-288) and home to the [United Nations headquarters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Headquarters_of_the_United_Nations "Headquarters of the United Nations").[[270]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-289)
triples.statement: The United States is a permanent member of the United Nations Security Council and is home to the United Nations headquarters.

triples.sentence: The United States is a member of the [G7](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G7 "G7"),[[271]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-290)[G20](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G20 "G20"),[[272]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-291) and [OECD](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OECD "OECD") intergovernmental organizations.[[273]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-292)
triples.statement: The United States is a member of the G7, G20, and OECD intergovernmental organizations.

triples.sentence: Likewise, nearly all countries host formal [diplomatic missions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diplomatic_mission "Diplomatic mission") with the United States, except [Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Iranâ€“United States relations"),[[274]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-293)[North Korea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Korea%E2%80%93United_States_relations "North Koreaâ€“United States relations"),[[275]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-294) and [Bhutan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Bhutan#Other_countries "Foreign relations of Bhutan").[[276]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-295)
triples.statement: Nearly all countries host formal diplomatic missions with the United States, with the exceptions of Iran, North Korea, and Bhutan.

triples.sentence: The United States has a "[Special Relationship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special_Relationship "Special Relationship")" [with the United Kingdom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom%E2%80%93United_States_relations "United Kingdomâ€“United States relations")[[280]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-299) and strong ties [with Canada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Canadaâ€“United States relations"),[[281]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-300)[Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Australiaâ€“United States relations"),[[282]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-301)[New Zealand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand%E2%80%93United_States_relations "New Zealandâ€“United States relations"),[[283]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-302)[the Philippines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philippines%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Philippinesâ€“United States relations"),[[284]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-303)[Japan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Japanâ€“United States relations"),[[285]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-304)[South Korea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Korea%E2%80%93United_States_relations "South Koreaâ€“United States relations"),[[286]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-305)[Israel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Israelâ€“United States relations"),[[287]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-306) and several [European Union countries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union "Member state of the European Union") such as [France](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/France%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Franceâ€“United States relations"), [Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italy%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Italyâ€“United States relations"), [Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Germany%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Germanyâ€“United States relations"), [Spain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spain%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Spainâ€“United States relations"), and [Poland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poland%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Polandâ€“United States relations").[[288]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-307)
triples.statement: The United States has a "Special Relationship" with the United Kingdom and strong ties with Canada, Australia, New Zealand, the Philippines, Japan, South Korea, Israel, and several European Union countries including France, Italy, Germany, Spain, and Poland.

triples.sentence: It has increasingly conducted strategic cooperation [with India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Indiaâ€“United States relations"),[[289]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-308) while [its ties with China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Chinaâ€“United States relations") have steadily deteriorated.[[290]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-309)[[291]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-310)
triples.statement: The U.S. has increased its strategic cooperation with India, while its relations with China have steadily worsened.

triples.sentence: Trump also ended U.S. intelligence sharing with the country,[[296]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-:5-315) but this too was eventually restored.[[297]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-316)
triples.statement: Trump also ended U.S. intelligence sharing with Ukraine, but it was eventually restored.

section_body:
Main article: [United States Armed Forces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces "United States Armed Forces")

[![Image 49](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/The_Pentagon%2C_Headquarters_of_the_US_Department_of_Defense_%28cropped2%29.jpg/250px-The_Pentagon%2C_Headquarters_of_the_US_Department_of_Defense_%28cropped2%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:The_Pentagon,_Headquarters_of_the_US_Department_of_Defense_(cropped2).jpg)

[The Pentagon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Pentagon "The Pentagon"), the headquarters of the [U.S. Department of Defense](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Defense "United States Department of Defense") in [Arlington County, Virginia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arlington_County,_Virginia "Arlington County, Virginia"), is one of the world's largest office buildings with over 6.5 million square feet (600,000 m 2) of [floor space](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floor_space "Floor space").

The president is the [commander-in-chief](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commander-in-Chief_of_the_United_States "Commander-in-Chief of the United States") of the United States Armed Forces and appoints its leaders, the [secretary of defense](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_Defense "United States Secretary of Defense") and the [Joint Chiefs of Staff](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joint_Chiefs_of_Staff "Joint Chiefs of Staff"). The [Department of Defense](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Defense "United States Department of Defense"), headquartered at [the Pentagon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Pentagon "The Pentagon") near Washington, D.C., administers five of the six service branches, which are made up of the [U.S. Army](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Army "United States Army"), [Marine Corps](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Marine_Corps "United States Marine Corps"), [Navy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Navy "United States Navy"), [Air Force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Air_Force "United States Air Force"), and [Space Force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Space_Force "United States Space Force").[[298]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-317) The [Coast Guard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Coast_Guard "United States Coast Guard") is administered by the [Department of Homeland Security](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Homeland_Security "United States Department of Homeland Security") in peacetime and can be transferred to the [Department of the Navy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_the_Navy "United States Department of the Navy") in wartime.[[299]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-318)

The United States [spent $997 billion on its military](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_budget_of_the_United_States "Military budget of the United States") in 2024, which is by far the [largest amount of any country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_with_highest_military_expenditures "List of countries with highest military expenditures"), making up 37% of global military spending and accounting for 3.4% of the country's GDP._**[[300]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United\_States#cite\_note-SIPRI-20202-319)**_ The [U.S. possesses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_weapons_of_the_United_States "Nuclear weapons of the United States") 42% of the world's nuclear weaponsâ€”the second-largest stockpile after [that of Russia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russia_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction "Russia and weapons of mass destruction").[[301]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Stockholm_International_Peace_Research_Institute-2024-320) The U.S. military is widely regarded as the most powerful and advanced in the world.[[302]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-321)[[303]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-322)

The United States has the [third-largest combined armed forces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_military_and_paramilitary_personnel "List of countries by number of military and paramilitary personnel") in the world, behind the [Chinese People's Liberation Army](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army "People's Liberation Army") and [Indian Armed Forces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Armed_Forces "Indian Armed Forces").[[304]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-323) The U.S. military operates about 800 bases and facilities abroad,[[305]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-324) and maintains [deployments greater than 100 active duty personnel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_military_deployments "United States military deployments") in 25 foreign countries.[[306]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-325) The United States has engaged in over 400 military interventions since its founding in 1776, with over half of these occurring between 1950 and 2019 and 25% occurring in the post-Cold War era.[[307]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-326)

[State defense forces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_defense_forces "State defense forces") (SDFs) are military units that operate under the sole authority of a state government. SDFs are authorized by state and federal law but are under the command of [the state's governor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Governor_(United_States) "Governor (United States)").[[308]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-327)[[309]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-328)[[310]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-329) By contrast, a state's [National Guard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Guard_(United_States) "National Guard (United States)") units are under the dual control of [state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_governments_of_the_United_States "State governments of the United States") and [federal governments](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States "Federal government of the United States"); such units can also become federalized entities, but SDFs cannot be federalized.[[311]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-330) A state's National Guard personnel can be federalized by the president under the [National Defense Act Amendments of 1933](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Defense_Act_of_1916#National_Defense_Act_Amendments_of_1933 "National Defense Act of 1916"), which created the Guard and provides for the integration of [Army National Guard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Army_National_Guard "Army National Guard")&[Air National Guard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_National_Guard "Air National Guard") units and personnel into the U.S. Army and (since 1947) the U.S. Air Force.[[312]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-331)

triples.sentence: The United States has the [third-largest combined armed forces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_military_and_paramilitary_personnel "List of countries by number of military and paramilitary personnel") in the world, behind the [Chinese People's Liberation Army](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army "People's Liberation Army") and [Indian Armed Forces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Armed_Forces "Indian Armed Forces").[[304]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-323)
triples.statement: The United States has the third-largest combined armed forces in the world, after the Chinese People's Liberation Army and Indian Armed Forces.

section_body:
Main articles: [Law of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_of_the_United_States "Law of the United States"), [Law enforcement in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_the_United_States "Law enforcement in the United States"), and [Crime in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crime_in_the_United_States "Crime in the United States")

[![Image 50](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/FBI_Headquarters_-_J._Edgar_Hoover_Building_%2853840035941%29.jpg/250px-FBI_Headquarters_-_J._Edgar_Hoover_Building_%2853840035941%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:FBI_Headquarters_-_J._Edgar_Hoover_Building_(53840035941).jpg)

[J. Edgar Hoover Building](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._Edgar_Hoover_Building "J. Edgar Hoover Building"), the headquarters of the [Federal Bureau of Investigation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation "Federal Bureau of Investigation") (FBI), in [Washington, D.C.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C.")

There are about 18,000 U.S. police agencies from local to national level in the United States.[[313]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-332) Law in the United States is mainly enforced by local police departments and [sheriff departments](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sheriffs_in_the_United_States "Sheriffs in the United States") in their municipal or county jurisdictions. [The state police](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_police_(United_States) "State police (United States)") departments [have authority in their respective state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Police_power_(United_States_constitutional_law) "Police power (United States constitutional law)"), and [federal agencies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_law_enforcement_in_the_United_States "Federal law enforcement in the United States") such as the [Federal Bureau of Investigation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation "Federal Bureau of Investigation") (FBI) and the [U.S. Marshals Service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Marshals_Service "United States Marshals Service") have national jurisdiction and specialized duties, such as protecting [civil rights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_rights "Civil rights"), [national security](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_security_of_the_United_States "National security of the United States"), enforcing [U.S. federal courts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._federal_courts "U.S. federal courts")' rulings and federal laws, and interstate criminal activity.[[314]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-333)[State courts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_court_(United_States) "State court (United States)") conduct almost all civil and criminal trials,[[315]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-334) while federal courts [adjudicate the much smaller number of civil and criminal cases that relate to federal law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subject-matter_jurisdiction "Subject-matter jurisdiction").[[316]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-335)

There is no unified "criminal justice system" in the United States. The [American prison system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Incarceration_in_the_United_States "Incarceration in the United States") is largely heterogenous, with thousands of relatively independent systems operating across federal, state, local, and tribal levels. In 2025, "these systems hold [nearly 2 million people](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_incarceration_rate "United States incarceration rate") in 1,566 state prisons, 98 federal prisons, 3,116 local jails, 1,277 juvenile correctional facilities, 133 immigration detention facilities, and 80 Indian country jails, as well as in military prisons, civil commitment centers, state psychiatric hospitals, and prisons in the U.S. territories."[[317]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Sawyer-2025-336)

Despite disparate systems of confinement, four main institutions dominate: [federal prisons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_federal_prisons "List of United States federal prisons"), [state prisons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lists_of_United_States_state_prisons "Lists of United States state prisons"), local jails, and [juvenile correctional facilities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_juvenile_justice_system "American juvenile justice system").[[318]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-National_Academies_Press-2014-337) Federal prisons are run by the [Federal Bureau of Prisons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Prisons "Federal Bureau of Prisons") and hold pretrial detainees as well as people who have been convicted of federal crimes.[[318]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-National_Academies_Press-2014-337) State prisons, run by the department of corrections of each state, hold people sentenced and serving prison time (usually longer than one year) for felony offenses.[[318]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-National_Academies_Press-2014-337) Local jails are county or municipal facilities that incarcerate defendants prior to trial; they also hold those serving short sentences (typically under a year).[[318]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-National_Academies_Press-2014-337) Juvenile correctional facilities are operated by local or state governments and serve as longer-term placements for any [minor adjudicated as delinquent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juvenile_delinquency "Juvenile delinquency") and ordered by a judge to be confined.[[319]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-338)

In January 2023, the United States had the [sixth-highest per capita incarceration rate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_incarceration_rate "List of countries by incarceration rate") in the worldâ€”531 people per 100,000 inhabitantsâ€”and the largest prison and jail population in the world, with more than 1.9 million people incarcerated.[[317]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Sawyer-2025-336)[[320]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-339)[[321]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-WorldPrisonBrief-340) An analysis of the [World Health Organization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Health_Organization "World Health Organization") Mortality Database from 2010 showed U.S. homicide rates "were 7 times higher than in other high-income countries, driven by [a gun homicide rate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gun_deaths_in_the_United_States "Gun deaths in the United States") that was 25 times higher".[[322]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-341)

triples.sentence: [State courts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_court_(United_States) "State court (United States)") conduct almost all civil and criminal trials,[[315]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-334) while federal courts [adjudicate the much smaller number of civil and criminal cases that relate to federal law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subject-matter_jurisdiction "Subject-matter jurisdiction").[[316]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-335)
triples.statement: State courts handle nearly all civil and criminal trials, while federal courts adjudicate the much smaller number of cases related to federal law.

triples.sentence: An analysis of the [World Health Organization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Health_Organization "World Health Organization") Mortality Database from 2010 showed U.S. homicide rates "were 7 times higher than in other high-income countries, driven by [a gun homicide rate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gun_deaths_in_the_United_States "Gun deaths in the United States") that was 25 times higher".[[322]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-341)
triples.statement: A 2010 analysis of the World Health Organization Mortality Database revealed that U.S. homicide rates were seven times higher than in other high-income countries, driven by a gun homicide rate that was 25 times higher.

section_body:
Main article: [Economy of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_the_United_States "Economy of the United States")

[![Image 51: see caption](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/US_one_dollar_bill%2C_obverse%2C_series_2009.jpg/250px-US_one_dollar_bill%2C_obverse%2C_series_2009.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:US_one_dollar_bill,_obverse,_series_2009.jpg)

The [U.S. dollar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_dollar "United States dollar") is the most-used currency [in international transactions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_use_of_the_U.S._dollar "International use of the U.S. dollar") and the world's foremost [reserve currency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reserve_currency "Reserve currency").

The U.S. has a highly developed [mixed economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mixed_economy "Mixed economy")[[323]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-342) that has been the world's largest nominally [since about 1890](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_largest_historical_GDP "List of countries by largest historical GDP").[[324]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-343) Its 2024 [gross domestic product](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gross_domestic_product "Gross domestic product") (GDP)[[e]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-PPP-20) of more than $29 trillion[[325]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-344) constituted over 25% of nominal [global economic output](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gross_world_product "Gross world product"), or 15% at [purchasing power parity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity "Purchasing power parity") (PPP). From 1983 to 2008, U.S. real compounded annual GDP growth was 3.3%, compared to a 2.3% weighted average for the rest of the [G7](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G7 "G7").[[326]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Hagopian-345) The country ranks [first in the world by nominal GDP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal) "List of countries by GDP (nominal)"),[[327]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-346)[second when adjusted for purchasing power parities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP) "List of countries by GDP (PPP)") (PPP),[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-IMFWEO.US-19) and [ninth by PPP-adjusted GDP per capita](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)_per_capita "List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita").[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-IMFWEO.US-19) In February 2024, the total [U.S. federal government debt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_debt_of_the_United_States "National debt of the United States") was $34.4 trillion.[[328]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-347)

[![Image 52](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/View_of_Empire_State_Building_from_Rockefeller_Center_New_York_City_dllu_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-View_of_Empire_State_Building_from_Rockefeller_Center_New_York_City_dllu_%28cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:View_of_Empire_State_Building_from_Rockefeller_Center_New_York_City_dllu_(cropped).jpg)

[New York City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") is the world's principal [financial center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_center "Financial center"), and [its metropolitan area](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_metropolitan_area "New York metropolitan area") is the world's [largest metropolitan economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_cities_by_GDP "List of cities by GDP").

Of the world's [500 largest companies by revenue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fortune_Global_500 "Fortune Global 500"), [138 were headquartered in the U.S.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_largest_companies_in_the_United_States_by_revenue "List of largest companies in the United States by revenue") in 2025,[[329]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Fortune-2025-348) the highest number of any country.[[330]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-349) The [U.S. dollar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_dollar "United States dollar") is the currency most used [in international transactions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_use_of_the_U.S._dollar "International use of the U.S. dollar") and the world's foremost [reserve currency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reserve_currency "Reserve currency"), backed by the country's dominant economy, [its military](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces "United States Armed Forces"), the [petrodollar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petrodollar "Petrodollar") system, its large [U.S. treasuries market](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Treasury "U.S. Treasury"), and its linked [eurodollar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurodollar "Eurodollar").[[331]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-federalreserve.gov-350)[Several countries use it as their official currency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_dollar#Countries_that_use_US_dollar "United States dollar"), and in others it is the [_de facto_ currency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_facto_currency "De facto currency").[[332]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Benjamin_J._Cohen_2006,_p._17-351)[[333]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-352) The U.S. has [free trade agreements](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_trade_agreements "Free trade agreements") with [several countries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_trade_agreements_of_the_United_States "Free trade agreements of the United States"), including the [USMCA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States%E2%80%93Mexico%E2%80%93Canada_Agreement "United Statesâ€“Mexicoâ€“Canada Agreement").[[334]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-353) Although the United States has reached a [post-industrial level of economic development](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post-industrial_economy "Post-industrial economy")[[335]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Collins-2023-354) and is often described as having a [service economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Service_economy "Service economy"),[[335]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Collins-2023-354)[[336]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Econ-355) it remains a major industrial power;[[337]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-356) in 2024, the [U.S. manufacturing sector](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._manufacturing_sector "U.S. manufacturing sector") was the world's [second-largest by value output](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_manufacturing_output "List of countries by manufacturing output") after [China's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manufacturing_in_China "Manufacturing in China").[[338]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-357)

[![Image 53](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Gaming-Wall-Street_BTS_Prodigium-266.jpg/250px-Gaming-Wall-Street_BTS_Prodigium-266.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Gaming-Wall-Street_BTS_Prodigium-266.jpg)

The [New York Stock Exchange](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Stock_Exchange "New York Stock Exchange") on [Wall Street](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wall_Street "Wall Street"), the world's [largest stock exchange by market capitalization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_stock_exchanges#Major_stock_exchanges "List of stock exchanges")[[339]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-NYSEhighestcap-358)

[New York City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") is the world's principal [financial center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_center "Financial center"),[[340]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-359)[[341]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-NYCFintechAndFinancialCapitalWorld-360) and [its metropolitan area](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_metropolitan_area "New York metropolitan area") is the world's [largest metropolitan economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_cities_by_GDP "List of cities by GDP").[[342]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-NYCEpicenterUSMetroEconomy-361) The [New York Stock Exchange](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Stock_Exchange "New York Stock Exchange") and [Nasdaq](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nasdaq "Nasdaq"), both located in New York City, are the world's two [largest stock exchanges](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_stock_exchanges "List of stock exchanges") by [market capitalization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Market_capitalization "Market capitalization") and [trade volume](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trade_volume "Trade volume").[[343]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-362)[[344]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-sfc.hk-363) The United States is at the forefront of [technological advancement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_the_United_States "Science and technology in the United States") and [innovation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Innovation "Innovation") in many economic fields, especially in [artificial intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence "Artificial intelligence"); [electronics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electronics "Electronics") and [computers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer "Computer"); [pharmaceuticals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pharmaceuticals "Pharmaceuticals"); and medical, [aerospace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aerospace "Aerospace") and [military equipment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_equipment "Military equipment").[[345]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-CIA-2018-364) The country's economy is fueled by abundant [natural resources](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_resource "Natural resource"), a well-developed [infrastructure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infrastructure_policy_of_the_United_States "Infrastructure policy of the United States"), and [high productivity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_labour_productivity "List of countries by labour productivity").[[346]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Wright,_Gavin_2007_p._185-365) The [largest trading partners of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_the_largest_trading_partners_of_the_United_States "List of the largest trading partners of the United States") are the [European Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Union "European Union"), Mexico, Canada, China, Japan, South Korea, the United Kingdom, Vietnam, India, and Taiwan.[[347]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-366) The United States is the world's [largest importer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_imports "List of countries by imports") and [second-largest exporter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_exports "List of countries by exports").[[t]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-369) It is by far the world's [largest exporter of services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_service_exports "List of countries by service exports").[[350]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-370)

Americans have the highest average [household](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Household_income "Household income")[[351]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-371) and [employee income](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_average_wage "List of countries by average wage") among OECD member states, and the fourth-highest [median household income](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Median_income "Median income") in 2023,[[352]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-372) up from sixth-highest in 2013.[[353]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Household_Income-373) With personal [consumption expenditures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumer_spending "Consumer spending") of over $18.5 trillion in 2023,[[354]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-374) the U.S. has a heavily [consumer-driven economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumer_economy "Consumer economy") and is the world's [largest consumer market](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_largest_consumer_markets "List of largest consumer markets").[[355]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-375) The U.S. [ranked first in the number of dollar billionaires](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_billionaires "List of countries by number of billionaires") and [millionaires](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_millionaires "List of countries by number of millionaires") in 2023, with 735 billionaires and nearly 22 million millionaires.[[356]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-376)

[Wealth in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wealth_in_the_United_States "Wealth in the United States") is highly concentrated; in 2011, the richest 10% of the adult population owned 72% of the country's household wealth, while the bottom 50% owned just 2%.[[357]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-377)[U.S. wealth inequality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wealth_inequality_in_the_United_States "Wealth inequality in the United States") increased substantially since the late 1980s,[[358]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Smith-2022-378) and [income inequality in the U.S.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Income_inequality_in_the_United_States "Income inequality in the United States") reached a record high in 2019.[[359]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-379) In 2024, the country had some of the highest wealth and income inequality levels among [OECD](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OECD "OECD") countries.[[360]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-380) Since the 1970s, there has been a decoupling of U.S. wage gains from worker productivity.[[361]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Hopkin-381) In 2016, the top fifth of earners took home more than half of all income,[[362]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-382) giving the U.S. one of the widest income distributions among OECD countries.[[363]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Sme-383)[[361]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Hopkin-381) There were about 771,480 [homeless persons in the U.S.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homelessness_in_the_United_States "Homelessness in the United States") in 2024.[[364]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-384) In 2022, 6.4 million children experienced food insecurity.[[365]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-ers.usda.gov-385)[Feeding America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feeding_America "Feeding America") estimates that around one in five, or approximately 13 million, [children experience hunger in the U.S.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunger_in_the_United_States#Children "Hunger in the United States") and do not know where or when they will get their next meal.[[366]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FactsAbout-386) Also in 2022, about 37.9 million people, or 11.5% of the U.S. population, were [living in poverty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poverty_in_the_United_States "Poverty in the United States").[[367]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-387)

The United States has a smaller [welfare state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welfare_state "Welfare state") and redistributes less income through government action than most other [high-income countries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Bank_high-income_economy "World Bank high-income economy").[[368]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-388)[[369]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-389) It is the only [advanced economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_economy "Advanced economy") that does not [guarantee its workers paid vacation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_statutory_minimum_employment_leave_by_country "List of statutory minimum employment leave by country") nationally[[370]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-390) and one of a few countries in the world without federal [paid family leave](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parental_leave_in_the_United_States "Parental leave in the United States") as a legal right.[[371]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-391) The United States has a higher percentage of low-income [workers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Working_class_in_the_United_States "Working class in the United States") than almost any other developed country, largely because of a weak [collective bargaining](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_bargaining "Collective bargaining") system and lack of government support for at-risk workers.[[372]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-392)

triples.sentence: The country ranks [first in the world by nominal GDP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal) "List of countries by GDP (nominal)"),[[327]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-346)[second when adjusted for purchasing power parities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP) "List of countries by GDP (PPP)") (PPP),[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-IMFWEO.US-19) and [ninth by PPP-adjusted GDP per capita](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)_per_capita "List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita").[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-IMFWEO.US-19)
triples.statement: The U.S. ranks first globally by nominal GDP, second by GDP adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP), and ninth by PPP-adjusted GDP per capita.

triples.sentence: [Several countries use it as their official currency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_dollar#Countries_that_use_US_dollar "United States dollar"), and in others it is the [_de facto_ currency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_facto_currency "De facto currency").[[332]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Benjamin_J._Cohen_2006,_p._17-351)[[333]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-352)
triples.statement: Several countries use the U.S. dollar as their official currency, while others use it as a de facto currency.

triples.sentence: The [New York Stock Exchange](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Stock_Exchange "New York Stock Exchange") and [Nasdaq](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nasdaq "Nasdaq"), both located in New York City, are the world's two [largest stock exchanges](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_stock_exchanges "List of stock exchanges") by [market capitalization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Market_capitalization "Market capitalization") and [trade volume](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trade_volume "Trade volume").[[343]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-362)[[344]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-sfc.hk-363)
triples.statement: The New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq, both in New York City, are the world's two largest stock exchanges by market capitalization and trade volume.

triples.sentence: The country's economy is fueled by abundant [natural resources](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_resource "Natural resource"), a well-developed [infrastructure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infrastructure_policy_of_the_United_States "Infrastructure policy of the United States"), and [high productivity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_labour_productivity "List of countries by labour productivity").[[346]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Wright,_Gavin_2007_p._185-365)
triples.statement: The U.S. economy is driven by abundant natural resources, well-developed infrastructure, and high productivity.

triples.sentence: With personal [consumption expenditures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumer_spending "Consumer spending") of over $18.5 trillion in 2023,[[354]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-374) the U.S. has a heavily [consumer-driven economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumer_economy "Consumer economy") and is the world's [largest consumer market](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_largest_consumer_markets "List of largest consumer markets").[[355]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-375)
triples.statement: The U.S. has a consumer-driven economy and is the world's largest consumer market, with personal consumption expenditures exceeding $18.5 trillion in 2023.

triples.sentence: [U.S. wealth inequality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wealth_inequality_in_the_United_States "Wealth inequality in the United States") increased substantially since the late 1980s,[[358]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Smith-2022-378) and [income inequality in the U.S.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Income_inequality_in_the_United_States "Income inequality in the United States") reached a record high in 2019.[[359]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-379)
triples.statement: U.S. wealth inequality has significantly increased since the late 1980s, and income inequality reached a record high in 2019.

triples.sentence: Since the 1970s, there has been a decoupling of U.S. wage gains from worker productivity.[[361]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Hopkin-381)
triples.statement: Since the 1970s, U.S. wage gains have not kept pace with worker productivity.

triples.sentence: In 2016, the top fifth of earners took home more than half of all income,[[362]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-382) giving the U.S. one of the widest income distributions among OECD countries.[[363]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Sme-383)[[361]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Hopkin-381)
triples.statement: In 2016, the top 20% of earners received more than half of all income, contributing to one of the widest income distributions among OECD countries.

triples.sentence: The United States has a smaller [welfare state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welfare_state "Welfare state") and redistributes less income through government action than most other [high-income countries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Bank_high-income_economy "World Bank high-income economy").[[368]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-388)[[369]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-389)
triples.statement: Compared to most other high-income countries, the United States has a smaller welfare state and redistributes less income via government action.

triples.sentence: The United States has a higher percentage of low-income [workers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Working_class_in_the_United_States "Working class in the United States") than almost any other developed country, largely because of a weak [collective bargaining](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_bargaining "Collective bargaining") system and lack of government support for at-risk workers.[[372]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-392)
triples.statement: The U.S. has a higher percentage of low-income workers than most other developed countries, attributed mainly to a weak collective bargaining system and insufficient government support for at-risk workers.

section_body:
Main article: [Space policy of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_policy_of_the_United_States "Space policy of the United States")

[![Image 55](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/A_Man_on_the_Moon%2C_AS11-40-5903_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-A_Man_on_the_Moon%2C_AS11-40-5903_%28cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:A_Man_on_the_Moon,_AS11-40-5903_(cropped).jpg)

Astronauts [Buzz Aldrin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buzz_Aldrin "Buzz Aldrin") and [Neil Armstrong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neil_Armstrong "Neil Armstrong") (seen in visor reflection) during the 1969 [Apollo 11](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apollo_11 "Apollo 11") mission, the first crewed [Moon landing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moon_landing "Moon landing"). The United States is the only country to have landed humans on the Moon.

The United States has maintained a space program since the late 1950s, beginning with the establishment of the [National Aeronautics and Space Administration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NASA "NASA") (NASA) in 1958.[[388]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-408)[[389]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-409) NASA's [Apollo program](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apollo_program "Apollo program") (1961â€“1972) achieved the first crewed [Moon landing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moon_landing "Moon landing") with the 1969 [Apollo 11](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apollo_11 "Apollo 11") mission; it remains one of the agency's most significant milestones.[[390]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-410)[[391]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-411) Other major endeavors by NASA include the [Space Shuttle program](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Shuttle_program "Space Shuttle program") (1981â€“2011),[[392]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-412) the [Voyager program](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voyager_program "Voyager program") (1972â€“present), the [Hubble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubble_Space_Telescope "Hubble Space Telescope") and [James Webb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Webb_Space_Telescope "James Webb Space Telescope")[space telescopes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_telescope "Space telescope") (launched in 1990 and 2021, respectively),[[393]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-413)[[394]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-414) and the multi-mission [Mars Exploration Program](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mars_Exploration_Program "Mars Exploration Program") (_[Spirit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mars\_Exploration\_Rover "Mars Exploration Rover")_ and _[Opportunity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opportunity\_(rover) "Opportunity (rover)")_, _[Curiosity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curiosity\_(rover) "Curiosity (rover)"),_ and _[Perseverance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perseverance\_(rover) "Perseverance (rover)")_).[[395]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-415) NASA is one of five agencies collaborating on the [International Space Station](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Space_Station "International Space Station") (ISS);[[396]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-416) U.S. contributions to the ISS include several modules, including _[Destiny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Destiny\_(ISS\_module) "Destiny (ISS module)")_ (2001), _[Harmony](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harmony\_(ISS\_module) "Harmony (ISS module)")_ (2007), and _[Tranquility](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tranquility\_(ISS\_module) "Tranquility (ISS module)")_ (2010), as well as ongoing logistical and operational support.[[397]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-417)

The United States [private sector](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Private_sector "Private sector") dominates the global [commercial spaceflight industry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Private_spaceflight "Private spaceflight").[[398]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-418) Prominent American spaceflight contractors include [Blue Origin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue_Origin "Blue Origin"), [Boeing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing "Boeing"), [Lockheed Martin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lockheed_Martin "Lockheed Martin"), [Northrop Grumman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northrop_Grumman "Northrop Grumman"), and [SpaceX](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SpaceX "SpaceX"). NASA programs such as the [Commercial Crew Program](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commercial_Crew_Program "Commercial Crew Program"), [Commercial Resupply Services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commercial_Resupply_Services "Commercial Resupply Services"), [Commercial Lunar Payload Services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commercial_Lunar_Payload_Services "Commercial Lunar Payload Services"), and [NextSTEP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Next_Space_Technologies_for_Exploration_Partnerships "Next Space Technologies for Exploration Partnerships") have facilitated growing private-sector involvement in American spaceflight.[[399]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-419)

triples.sentence: NASA's [Apollo program](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apollo_program "Apollo program") (1961â€“1972) achieved the first crewed [Moon landing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moon_landing "Moon landing") with the 1969 [Apollo 11](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apollo_11 "Apollo 11") mission; it remains one of the agency's most significant milestones.[[390]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-410)[[391]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-411)
triples.statement: NASA's Apollo program (1961â€“1972) achieved the first crewed Moon landing with the 1969 Apollo 11 mission, which is one of the agency's most significant milestones.

section_body:
Main articles: [Americans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Americans "Americans") and [Race and ethnicity in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Race_and_ethnicity_in_the_United_States "Race and ethnicity in the United States")

See also: [List of U.S. states by population](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_U.S._states_by_population "List of U.S. states by population")

The 10 most populous U.S. states 

 (2024 estimates)[[424]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-CensusEst2024-444)| State | Population (millions) |
| --- | --- |
| [California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California "California") | 39.4 |
| [Texas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texas "Texas") | 31.3 |
| [Florida](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florida "Florida") | 23.4 |
| [New York](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_(state) "New York (state)") | 19.9 |
| [Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pennsylvania "Pennsylvania") | 13.1 |
| [Illinois](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Illinois "Illinois") | 12.7 |
| [Ohio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio "Ohio") | 11.9 |
| [Georgia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georgia_(U.S._state) "Georgia (U.S. state)") | 11.2 |
| [North Carolina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Carolina "North Carolina") | 11.0 |
| [Michigan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michigan "Michigan") | 10.1 |

The [U.S. Census Bureau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Census_Bureau "United States Census Bureau") reported 331,449,281 residents on April 1, 2020,[[u]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-445)[[425]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-2020CENSUS-446) making the United States the [third-most-populous country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population "List of countries and dependencies by population") in the world, after China and India.[[345]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-CIA-2018-364) The Census Bureau's official 2024 population estimate was 340,110,988, an increase of 2.6% since the 2020 census.[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Vintage2024-16) According to the Bureau's [U.S. Population Clock](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._and_World_Population_Clock "U.S. and World Population Clock"), on July 1, 2024, the U.S. population had a net gain of one person every 16 seconds, or about 5400 people per day.[[426]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-447) In 2023, 51% of Americans age 15 and over were married, 6% were [widowed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Widowed "Widowed"), 10% were divorced, and 34% had never been married.[[427]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-448) In 2023, the [total fertility rate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Total_fertility_rate "Total fertility rate") for the U.S. stood at 1.6 children per woman,[[428]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-449) and, at 23%, it had the world's highest rate of children living in [single-parent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Single_parents_in_the_United_States "Single parents in the United States") households in 2019.[[429]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-450)

The United States has a diverse population; 37 [ancestry groups](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_ancestries "American ancestries") have more than one million members.[[430]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-An2000-451)[White Americans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-Hispanic_whites "Non-Hispanic whites") with ancestry from Europe, the Middle East, or North Africa form the largest [racial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Race_(human_classification) "Race (human classification)") and [ethnic group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnic_group "Ethnic group") at 57.8% of the United States population.[[431]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-452)[[432]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-453)[Hispanic and Latino Americans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hispanic_and_Latino_Americans "Hispanic and Latino Americans") form the second-largest group and are 18.7% of the United States population. [African Americans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/African_Americans "African Americans") constitute the country's third-largest ancestry group and are 12.1% of the total U.S. population.[[430]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-An2000-451) Asian Americans are the country's fourth-largest group, composing 5.9% of the United States population. The country's 3.7 million Native Americans account for about 1%,[[430]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-An2000-451) and some 574 native tribes are recognized by the federal government.[[433]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-454) In 2024, the [median age](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Median_age "Median age") of the United States population was 39.1 years.[[434]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-455)

triples.sentence: The [U.S. Census Bureau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Census_Bureau "United States Census Bureau") reported 331,449,281 residents on April 1, 2020,[[u]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-445)[[425]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-2020CENSUS-446) making the United States the [third-most-populous country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population "List of countries and dependencies by population") in the world, after China and India.[[345]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-CIA-2018-364)
triples.statement: On April 1, 2020, the U.S. Census Bureau reported a population of 331,449,281, making the United States the third-most-populous country after China and India.

triples.sentence: The United States has a diverse population; 37 [ancestry groups](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_ancestries "American ancestries") have more than one million members.[[430]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-An2000-451)
triples.statement: The United States has 37 ancestry groups with over one million members each.

triples.sentence: [African Americans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/African_Americans "African Americans") constitute the country's third-largest ancestry group and are 12.1% of the total U.S. population.[[430]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-An2000-451)
triples.statement: African Americans are the third-largest ancestry group, making up 12.1% of the total U.S. population.

triples.sentence: The country's 3.7 million Native Americans account for about 1%,[[430]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-An2000-451) and some 574 native tribes are recognized by the federal government.[[433]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-454)
triples.statement: The 3.7 million Native Americans in the U.S. make up about 1% of the population, and the federal government recognizes 574 native tribes.

section_body:
Main article: [Languages of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Languages_of_the_United_States "Languages of the United States")

[![Image 58](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Languages_cp-02.svg/250px-Languages_cp-02.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Languages_cp-02.svg)

Most spoken languages in the U.S.

While many languages are spoken in the United States, [English](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_English "American English") is by far the most commonly spoken and written.[[435]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-456)_[De facto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De\_facto "De facto")_, English is the [official language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Official_language "Official language") of the United States, and in 2025, [Executive Order 14224](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Executive_Order_14224 "Executive Order 14224") declared English official.[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-EOWP-4) However, the U.S. has never had a _[de jure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De\_jure "De jure")_ official language, as Congress has never passed a law to designate English as official for all three federal branches. Some laws, such as [U.S. naturalization requirements](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naturalized_citizen_of_the_United_States "Naturalized citizen of the United States"), nonetheless standardize English. Twenty-eight states and the [United States Virgin Islands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Virgin_Islands "United States Virgin Islands") have laws that designate English as the sole official language; 19 states and the [District of Columbia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/District_of_Columbia "District of Columbia") have no official language.[[436]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-457) Three states and four U.S. territories have recognized local or indigenous languages in addition to English: Hawaii ([Hawaiian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hawaiian_language "Hawaiian language")),[[437]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-458) Alaska ([twenty Native languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alaska_Native_languages "Alaska Native languages")),[[v]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-459)[[438]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-460) South Dakota ([Sioux](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sioux_language "Sioux language")),[[439]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-LakotaCommon-461) American Samoa ([Samoan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samoan_language "Samoan language")), Puerto Rico ([Spanish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spanish_language_in_the_United_States "Spanish language in the United States")), Guam ([Chamorro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chamorro_language "Chamorro language")), and the Northern Mariana Islands ([Carolinian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carolinian_language "Carolinian language") and Chamorro). In total, 169 Native American languages are spoken in the United States.[[440]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-462) In Puerto Rico, Spanish is more widely spoken than English.[[441]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-PuertoRicoTranslation-463)

According to the [American Community Survey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Community_Survey "American Community Survey") (2020),[[442]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-ACS2021-464) some 245.4 million people in the U.S. age five and older spoke only English at home. About 41.2 million spoke Spanish at home, making it the second most commonly used language.
