Other languages spoken at home by one million people or more include [Chinese](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_language_in_the_United_States "Chinese language in the United States") (3.40 million), [Tagalog](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tagalog_language_in_the_United_States "Tagalog language in the United States") (1.71 million), [Vietnamese](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vietnamese_language_in_the_United_States "Vietnamese language in the United States") (1.52 million), [Arabic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arabic_language_in_the_United_States "Arabic language in the United States") (1.39 million), [French](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_language_in_the_United_States "French language in the United States") (1.18 million), [Korean](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Korean_language_in_the_United_States "Korean language in the United States") (1.07 million), and [Russian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_language_in_the_United_States "Russian language in the United States") (1.04 million). [German](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_language_in_the_United_States "German language in the United States"), spoken by 1 million people at home in 2010, fell to 857,000 total speakers in 2020.[[443]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-465)

triples.sentence: [German](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_language_in_the_United_States "German language in the United States"), spoken by 1 million people at home in 2010, fell to 857,000 total speakers in 2020.[[443]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-465)
triples.statement: The number of German speakers at home in the U.S. fell from 1 million in 2010 to 857,000 in 2020.

section_body:
Main article: [Immigration to the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Immigration_to_the_United_States "Immigration to the United States")

[![Image 59](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Border_USA_Mexico.jpg/250px-Border_USA_Mexico.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Border_USA_Mexico.jpg)

The [Mexicoâ€“United States border wall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mexico%E2%80%93United_States_border_wall "Mexicoâ€“United States border wall") between [San Diego](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Diego "San Diego") (left) and [Tijuana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tijuana "Tijuana") (right)

America's immigrant population is by far the world's [largest in absolute terms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependent_territories_by_immigrant_population "List of sovereign states and dependent territories by immigrant population").[[444]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-UNdef-466)[[445]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-467) In 2022, there were 87.7 million immigrants and [U.S.-born children of immigrants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second-generation_immigrants_in_the_United_States "Second-generation immigrants in the United States") in the United States, accounting for nearly 27% of the overall U.S. population.[[446]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-468) In 2017, out of the U.S. foreign-born population, some 45% (20.7 million) were naturalized citizens, 27% (12.3 million) were lawful permanent residents, 6% (2.2 million) were temporary lawful residents, and 23% (10.5 million) were [unauthorized immigrants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Undocumented_immigrant_population_of_the_United_States "Undocumented immigrant population of the United States").[[447]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-KeyFindings-469) In 2019, the top countries of origin for immigrants were Mexico (24% of immigrants), India (6%), China (5%), the Philippines (4.5%), and El Salvador (3%).[[448]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-470) In fiscal year 2022, over one million immigrants (most of whom entered through [family reunification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chain_migration#Legislation "Chain migration")) were granted [legal residence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Permanent_residence_(United_States) "Permanent residence (United States)").[[449]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-471) The undocumented immigrant population in the U.S. reached a record high of 14 million in 2023.[[450]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-472)

triples.sentence: America's immigrant population is by far the world's [largest in absolute terms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependent_territories_by_immigrant_population "List of sovereign states and dependent territories by immigrant population").[[444]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-UNdef-466)[[445]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-467)
triples.statement: The immigrant population of the United States is the world's largest in absolute terms.

section_body:
Main article: [Religion in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religion_in_the_United_States "Religion in the United States")

Religious affiliation in the U.S., according to a 2023 [Gallup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gallup,_Inc. "Gallup, Inc.") poll:[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Staff-2007-10)

1.   [Protestantism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protestantism_in_the_United_States "Protestantism in the United States") (33.0%)
2.   [Catholicism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_the_United_States "Catholic Church in the United States") (22.0%)
3.   [Non-specific Christian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christianity_in_the_United_States "Christianity in the United States") (11.0%)
4.   [Judaism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Judaism_in_the_United_States "Judaism in the United States") (2.00%)
5.   [Mormonism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mormonism_in_the_United_States "Mormonism in the United States") (1.00%)
6.   Other religion (6.00%)
7.   [Unaffiliated](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irreligion_in_the_United_States "Irreligion in the United States") (22.0%)
8.   Unanswered (3.00%)

The [First Amendment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "First Amendment to the United States Constitution") guarantees the [free exercise of religion in the country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_Exercise_Clause "Free Exercise Clause") and forbids Congress from passing laws respecting [its establishment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Establishment_Clause "Establishment Clause").[[451]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Donadio-2021-473)[[452]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-474) Religious practice is widespread, among the [most diverse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_ethnic_and_cultural_diversity_level "List of countries by ethnic and cultural diversity level") in the world,[[453]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-alesina1-475) and profoundly vibrant.

[[454]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-pewreligion-476) The country has the world's [largest Christian population](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christianity_by_country "Christianity by country"), which includes the [fourth-largest population of Catholics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catholic_Church_by_country "Catholic Church by country").[[455]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Global_Christianity-477) Other notable faiths include [Judaism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Judaism "Judaism"), [Buddhism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buddhism "Buddhism"), [Hinduism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hinduism "Hinduism"), [Islam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islam "Islam"), [New Age](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Age "New Age"), and [Native American religions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Native_American_religions "Native American religions").[[456]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-478) Religious practice varies significantly by region.[[457]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Williams-2023-479) "[Ceremonial deism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ceremonial_deism "Ceremonial deism")" is common in American culture.[[458]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-480)

The overwhelming majority of [Americans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Americans "Americans") believe in a [higher power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Higher_Power "Higher Power") or spiritual force, engage in [spiritual practices](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spiritual_practice "Spiritual practice") such as prayer, and consider themselves religious or [spiritual](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spirituality "Spirituality").[[459]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Kallo-2023-481)[[460]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-482) In the Southern United States' "[Bible Belt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bible_Belt "Bible Belt")", [evangelical Protestantism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evangelicalism "Evangelicalism") plays a significant role culturally; [New England](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_England "New England") and the Western United States [tend to be more secular](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unchurched_Belt "Unchurched Belt").[[457]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Williams-2023-479)[[461]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-483)[Mormonism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mormonism "Mormonism"), a [Restorationist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Restorationism "Restorationism") movement founded in the U.S. in 1847,[[462]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHowe2008727%E2%80%93728-484) is the predominant religion in Utah and a major religion in Idaho.

triples.sentence: Other notable faiths include [Judaism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Judaism "Judaism"), [Buddhism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buddhism "Buddhism"), [Hinduism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hinduism "Hinduism"), [Islam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islam "Islam"), [New Age](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Age "New Age"), and [Native American religions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Native_American_religions "Native American religions").[[456]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-478)
triples.statement: Other notable faiths in the U.S. include Judaism, Buddhism, Hinduism, Islam, New Age, and Native American religions.

triples.sentence: The overwhelming majority of [Americans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Americans "Americans") believe in a [higher power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Higher_Power "Higher Power") or spiritual force, engage in [spiritual practices](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spiritual_practice "Spiritual practice") such as prayer, and consider themselves religious or [spiritual](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spirituality "Spirituality").[[459]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Kallo-2023-481)[[460]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-482)
triples.statement: The overwhelming majority of Americans believe in a higher power or spiritual force, engage in spiritual practices such as prayer, and consider themselves religious or spiritual.

triples.sentence: [Mormonism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mormonism "Mormonism"), a [Restorationist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Restorationism "Restorationism") movement founded in the U.S. in 1847,[[462]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHowe2008727%E2%80%93728-484) is the predominant religion in Utah and a major religion in Idaho.
triples.statement: Mormonism, a Restorationist movement founded in the U.S. in 1847, is the predominant religion in Utah and a major religion in Idaho.

section_body:
Main articles: [Urbanization in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urbanization_in_the_United_States "Urbanization in the United States") and [List of United States cities by population](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_cities_by_population "List of United States cities by population")

About 82% of Americans live in [urban areas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_urban_area "United States urban area"), including suburbs;[[345]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-CIA-2018-364) about half of those reside in cities with populations over 50,000.[[463]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-485) In 2022, 333 [incorporated municipalities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_cities_by_population "List of United States cities by population") had populations over 100,000, nine cities had more than one million residents, and four citiesâ€”[New York City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"), [Los Angeles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles"), [Chicago](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago "Chicago"), and [Houston](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Houston "Houston")â€”had populations exceeding two million.[[464]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-486) Many U.S. metropolitan populations are growing rapidly, particularly in the South and West.[[465]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-487)

triples.sentence: About 82% of Americans live in [urban areas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_urban_area "United States urban area"), including suburbs;[[345]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-CIA-2018-364) about half of those reside in cities with populations over 50,000.[[463]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-485)
triples.statement: Approximately 82% of Americans live in urban areas, including suburbs, with about half of them residing in cities with populations over 50,000.

section_body:
Main article: [Health in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Health_in_the_United_States "Health in the United States")

Further information: [Healthcare in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Healthcare_in_the_United_States "Healthcare in the United States") and [Health insurance in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Health_insurance_in_the_United_States "Health insurance in the United States")

[![Image 60](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Texas_medical_center.jpg/250px-Texas_medical_center.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Texas_medical_center.jpg)

The [Texas Medical Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texas_Medical_Center "Texas Medical Center") in [Houston](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Houston "Houston") is the largest medical complex in the world.[[467]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-489)[[468]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-490) In 2018, it employed 120,000 people and treated 10 million patients.[[469]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-491)

According to the [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention "Centers for Disease Control and Prevention") (CDC), average American life expectancy at birth was 78.4 years in 2023 (75.8 years for men and 81.1 years for women). This was a gain of 0.9 year from 77.5 years in 2022, and the CDC noted that the new average was largely driven by "decreases in mortality due to COVID-19, heart disease, unintentional injuries, cancer and diabetes".[[470]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-492) Starting in 1998, life expectancy in the U.S. fell [behind that of other wealthy industrialized countries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy "List of countries by life expectancy"), and Americans' "health disadvantage" gap has been increasing ever since.[[471]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-493)

The Commonwealth Fund reported in 2020 that the U.S. had the [highest suicide rate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_suicide_rate "List of countries by suicide rate") among [high-income countries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High-income_countries "High-income countries").[[472]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-494)[Approximately one-third of the U.S. adult population is obese](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Obesity_in_the_United_States "Obesity in the United States") and another third is overweight.[[473]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-495) The U.S. healthcare system far [outspends that of any other country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_total_health_expenditure_(PPP)_per_capita "List of countries by total health expenditure (PPP) per capita"), measured both in per capita spending and as a percentage of GDP, but attains worse healthcare outcomes when compared to peer countries for reasons that are debated.[[474]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-496) The United States is the only developed country [without a system of universal healthcare](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Healthcare_reform_in_the_United_States "Healthcare reform in the United States"), and [a significant proportion of the population that does not carry health insurance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Health_insurance_coverage_in_the_United_States "Health insurance coverage in the United States").[[475]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-497) Government-funded healthcare coverage for the poor ([Medicaid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medicaid "Medicaid")) and for those age 65 and older ([Medicare](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medicare_(United_States) "Medicare (United States)")) is available to Americans who meet the programs' income or age qualifications. In 2010, then-President Obama passed the [Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patient_Protection_and_Affordable_Care_Act "Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act").[[w]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-498)[[476]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-499)[Abortion in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abortion_in_the_United_States "Abortion in the United States") is not federally protected, and is illegal or restricted in 17 states.[[477]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-500)

triples.sentence: [Approximately one-third of the U.S. adult population is obese](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Obesity_in_the_United_States "Obesity in the United States") and another third is overweight.[[473]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-495)
triples.statement: Approximately one-third of the U.S. adult population is obese and another third is overweight.

triples.sentence: In 2010, then-President Obama passed the [Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patient_Protection_and_Affordable_Care_Act "Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act").[[w]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-498)[[476]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-499)
triples.statement: In 2010, President Obama passed the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act.

section_body:
Main articles: [Culture of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Culture_of_the_United_States "Culture of the United States") and [Society of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Society_of_the_United_States "Society of the United States")

See also: [Human rights in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_rights_in_the_United_States "Human rights in the United States")

[![Image 62: The Statue of Liberty, a large teal bronze sculpture on a stone pedestal](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Statue_of_Liberty_frontal_2_crop.JPG/250px-Statue_of_Liberty_frontal_2_crop.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Statue_of_Liberty_frontal_2_crop.JPG)

The [Statue of Liberty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty "Statue of Liberty") (_Liberty Enlightening the World_) on [Liberty Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liberty_Island "Liberty Island") in [New York Harbor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Harbor "New York Harbor") was an 1866 gift from France that has become an iconic symbol of the [American Dream](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Dream "American Dream").[[493]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-516)

The United States is home to [a wide variety of ethnic groups, traditions, and customs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiculturalism_in_the_United_States "Multiculturalism in the United States").[[494]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-517)[[495]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-518) The country has been described as having [the values](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Americanism_(ideology) "Americanism (ideology)") of [individualism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Individualism "Individualism") and [personal autonomy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Left-libertarianism "Left-libertarianism"),[[496]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-519)[[497]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-520) as well as a strong [work ethic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Work_ethic "Work ethic")[[498]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-521) and [competitiveness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competition "Competition").[[499]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-522) Voluntary [altruism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altruism "Altruism") towards others also plays a major role;[[500]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-523)[[501]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-524)[[502]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-525) according to a 2016 study by the [Charities Aid Foundation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charities_Aid_Foundation "Charities Aid Foundation"), Americans donated 1.44% of total GDP to charityâ€”the [highest rate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_charitable_donation "List of countries by charitable donation") in the world by a large margin.[[503]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-526) Americans have traditionally [been characterized](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stereotypes_of_Americans "Stereotypes of Americans") by a unifying political belief in an "[American Creed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Creed "American Creed")" emphasizing [consent of the governed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consent_of_the_governed "Consent of the governed"), [liberty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liberty "Liberty"), [equality under the law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equality_under_the_law "Equality under the law"), [democracy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democracy "Democracy"), [social equality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_equality "Social equality"), [property rights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Property_rights "Property rights"), and a preference for [limited government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Limited_government "Limited government").[[504]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-527)[[505]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-528) The U.S. has acquired significant [hard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hard_power "Hard power") and [soft power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soft_power "Soft power") through [its diplomatic influence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_the_United_States "Foreign relations of the United States"), [economic power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_power "Economic power"), [military alliances](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_alliance "Military alliance"), and [cultural exports](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_exports "Cultural exports") such as [American movies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cinema_of_the_United_States "Cinema of the United States"), [music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Music_of_the_United_States "Music of the United States"), [video games](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_games_in_the_United_States "Video games in the United States"), [sports](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sports_in_the_United_States "Sports in the United States"), and [food](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_cuisine "American cuisine").[[506]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-529)[[507]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-530) The influence that the United States exerts on other countries through soft power is referred to as [Americanization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Americanization "Americanization").[[508]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-531)

Nearly all present Americans or their ancestors came from [Europe, Africa, or Asia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Afro-Eurasia "Afro-Eurasia") (the "[Old World](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_World "Old World")") within the past five centuries.[[509]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-532)[Mainstream](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mainstream "wikt:mainstream") American culture is a [Western culture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_culture "Western culture") largely derived from the [traditions of European immigrants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_American#Culture "European American") with influences from many other sources, such as [traditions brought by slaves from Africa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/African-American_culture "African-American culture").[[510]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-533) More recent immigration from [Asia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asian_American "Asian American") and especially [Latin America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_American_culture "Latin American culture") has added to a cultural mix that has been described as a homogenizing [melting pot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melting_pot "Melting pot"), and a heterogeneous [salad bowl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salad_bowl_(cultural_idea) "Salad bowl (cultural idea)"), with immigrants contributing to, and often [assimilating](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assimilation_(phonology) "Assimilation (phonology)") into, mainstream American culture.

Under the [First Amendment to the Constitution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "First Amendment to the United States Constitution"), the United States is considered to have the [strongest protections of free speech of any country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freedom_of_speech_in_the_United_States "Freedom of speech in the United States").[[511]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Coleman-2013-534)[Flag desecration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_desecration_in_the_United_States "Flag desecration in the United States"), [hate speech](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hate_speech_in_the_United_States "Hate speech in the United States"), [blasphemy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blasphemy_law_in_the_United_States "Blasphemy law in the United States"), and [lese majesty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/L%C3%A8se-majest%C3%A9 "LÃ¨se-majestÃ©") are all forms of protected expression.[[512]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-535)[[513]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-536)[[514]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-537) A 2016 [Pew Research Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pew_Research_Center "Pew Research Center") poll found that Americans were the most supportive of free expression of any polity measured.[[515]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-538) Additionally, they are the "most supportive of [freedom of the press](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press_in_the_United_States "Freedom of the press in the United States") and the [right to use the Internet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Right_to_Internet_access "Right to Internet access") without government censorship".[[516]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-539) The U.S. is a [socially progressive](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_liberalism "Cultural liberalism") country[[517]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-540) with [permissive](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Permissive_society "Permissive society") attitudes surrounding [human sexuality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_sexuality "Human sexuality").[[518]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Derks-2020-541)[LGBTQ rights in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LGBTQ_rights_in_the_United_States "LGBTQ rights in the United States") are among the most advanced by global standards.[[518]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Derks-2020-541)[[519]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-542)[[520]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-543)

The [American Dream](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Dream "American Dream"), or the perception that Americans enjoy high levels of [social mobility](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socio-economic_mobility_in_the_United_States "Socio-economic mobility in the United States"), plays a key role in attracting immigrants.[[521]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-544)[[522]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-545) Whether this perception is accurate has been a topic of debate.[[523]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-socialmobility-546)[[524]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-CAP-547)[[525]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-548) While mainstream culture holds that the United States is a [classless society](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classless_society "Classless society"),[[526]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-549) scholars identify significant differences between [the country's social classes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_class_in_the_United_States "Social class in the United States"), affecting [socialization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socialization "Socialization"), language, and values.[[527]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-550)[[528]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-551) Americans tend to greatly value [socioeconomic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socioeconomics "Socioeconomics") achievement, but [being ordinary or average](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Average_Joe "Average Joe") is promoted by some as a noble condition as well.[[529]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-552)

The [National Foundation on the Arts and the Humanities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Foundation_on_the_Arts_and_the_Humanities "National Foundation on the Arts and the Humanities") is an agency of the United States federal government that was established in 1965 with the purpose to "develop and promote a broadly conceived national policy of support for the humanities and the arts in the United States, and for institutions which preserve the cultural heritage of the United States."[[530]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-553) It is composed of four sub-agencies:

*   [National Endowment for the Arts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Endowment_for_the_Arts "National Endowment for the Arts")
*   [National Endowment for the Humanities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Endowment_for_the_Humanities "National Endowment for the Humanities")
*   [Institute of Museum and Library Services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Institute_of_Museum_and_Library_Services "Institute of Museum and Library Services")
*   [Federal Council on the Arts and the Humanities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Council_on_the_Arts_and_the_Humanities "Federal Council on the Arts and the Humanities")

triples.sentence: The United States is home to [a wide variety of ethnic groups, traditions, and customs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiculturalism_in_the_United_States "Multiculturalism in the United States").[[494]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-517)[[495]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-518)
triples.statement: The United States contains a wide variety of ethnic groups, traditions, and customs.

triples.sentence: The country has been described as having [the values](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Americanism_(ideology) "Americanism (ideology)") of [individualism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Individualism "Individualism") and [personal autonomy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Left-libertarianism "Left-libertarianism"),[[496]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-519)[[497]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-520) as well as a strong [work ethic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Work_ethic "Work ethic")[[498]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-521) and [competitiveness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competition "Competition").[[499]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-522)
triples.statement: The United States is described as having values of individualism, personal autonomy, a strong work ethic, and competitiveness.

triples.sentence: Americans have traditionally [been characterized](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stereotypes_of_Americans "Stereotypes of Americans") by a unifying political belief in an "[American Creed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Creed "American Creed")" emphasizing [consent of the governed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consent_of_the_governed "Consent of the governed"), [liberty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liberty "Liberty"), [equality under the law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equality_under_the_law "Equality under the law"), [democracy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democracy "Democracy"), [social equality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_equality "Social equality"), [property rights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Property_rights "Property rights"), and a preference for [limited government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Limited_government "Limited government").[[504]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-527)[[505]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-528)
triples.statement: Americans are traditionally characterized by a belief in an 'American Creed' that emphasizes principles like consent of the governed, liberty, equality, democracy, and limited government.

triples.sentence: The influence that the United States exerts on other countries through soft power is referred to as [Americanization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Americanization "Americanization").[[508]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-531)
triples.statement: The soft power influence of the United States on other countries is known as Americanization.

triples.sentence: Nearly all present Americans or their ancestors came from [Europe, Africa, or Asia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Afro-Eurasia "Afro-Eurasia") (the "[Old World](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_World "Old World")") within the past five centuries.[[509]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-532)
triples.statement: Nearly all current Americans or their ancestors have immigrated from Europe, Africa, or Asia within the last 500 years.

triples.sentence: [Mainstream](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mainstream "wikt:mainstream") American culture is a [Western culture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_culture "Western culture") largely derived from the [traditions of European immigrants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_American#Culture "European American") with influences from many other sources, such as [traditions brought by slaves from Africa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/African-American_culture "African-American culture").[[510]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-533)
triples.statement: Mainstream American culture is a Western culture primarily derived from European immigrant traditions, with influences from other sources including traditions from African slaves.

triples.sentence: Under the [First Amendment to the Constitution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "First Amendment to the United States Constitution"), the United States is considered to have the [strongest protections of free speech of any country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freedom_of_speech_in_the_United_States "Freedom of speech in the United States").[[511]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Coleman-2013-534)
triples.statement: The United States is considered to have the world's strongest free speech protections under the First Amendment.

triples.sentence: The U.S. is a [socially progressive](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_liberalism "Cultural liberalism") country[[517]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-540) with [permissive](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Permissive_society "Permissive society") attitudes surrounding [human sexuality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_sexuality "Human sexuality").[[518]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Derks-2020-541)
triples.statement: The U.S. is a socially progressive country with permissive attitudes regarding human sexuality.

triples.sentence: [LGBTQ rights in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LGBTQ_rights_in_the_United_States "LGBTQ rights in the United States") are among the most advanced by global standards.[[518]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Derks-2020-541)[[519]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-542)[[520]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-543)
triples.statement: LGBTQ rights in the United States are considered among the most advanced in the world.

triples.sentence: Whether this perception is accurate has been a topic of debate.[[523]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-socialmobility-546)[[524]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-CAP-547)[[525]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-548)
triples.statement: The accuracy of the perception of high social mobility in the U.S. is a subject of debate.

triples.sentence: While mainstream culture holds that the United States is a [classless society](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classless_society "Classless society"),[[526]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-549) scholars identify significant differences between [the country's social classes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_class_in_the_United_States "Social class in the United States"), affecting [socialization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socialization "Socialization"), language, and values.[[527]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-550)[[528]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-551)
triples.statement: Although mainstream culture suggests the U.S. is a classless society, scholars note significant differences among social classes that impact socialization, language, and values.

section_body:
Main article: [American literature](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_literature "American literature")

See also: [American philosophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_philosophy "American philosophy")

[![Image 63: Photograph of Mark Twain](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Mark_Twain_by_AF_Bradley.jpg/250px-Mark_Twain_by_AF_Bradley.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Mark_Twain_by_AF_Bradley.jpg)

[Mark Twain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Twain "Mark Twain"), whom [William Faulkner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Faulkner "William Faulkner") called "the father of American literature"[[531]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-faulkner-554)

Colonial American authors were influenced by [John Locke](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Locke "John Locke") and other [Enlightenment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment "Age of Enlightenment") philosophers.[[532]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine2013157%E2%80%93159-555)[[533]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTELauter1994a503%E2%80%93509-556) The [American Revolutionary Period](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Revolution "American Revolution") (1765â€“1783) is notable for the political writings of [Benjamin Franklin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benjamin_Franklin "Benjamin Franklin"), [Alexander Hamilton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Hamilton "Alexander Hamilton"), [Thomas Paine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Paine "Thomas Paine"), and [Thomas Jefferson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson "Thomas Jefferson"). Shortly before and after the [Revolutionary War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War "American Revolutionary War"), the newspaper rose to prominence, filling a demand for anti-British national literature.[[534]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine2013163-557)[[535]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-558) An early novel is [William Hill Brown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Hill_Brown "William Hill Brown")'s _[The Power of Sympathy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Power\_of\_Sympathy "The Power of Sympathy")_, published in 1791. Writer and critic [John Neal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Neal "John Neal") in the early- to mid-19th century helped advance America toward a unique literature and culture by criticizing predecessors such as [Washington Irving](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Irving "Washington Irving") for imitating their British counterparts, and by influencing writers such as [Edgar Allan Poe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edgar_Allan_Poe "Edgar Allan Poe"),[[536]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-559) who took American poetry and short fiction in new directions. [Ralph Waldo Emerson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ralph_Waldo_Emerson "Ralph Waldo Emerson") and [Margaret Fuller](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Margaret_Fuller "Margaret Fuller") pioneered the influential [Transcendentalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transcendentalism "Transcendentalism") movement;[[537]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-560)[[538]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Coviello-561)[Henry David Thoreau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_David_Thoreau "Henry David Thoreau"), author of _[Walden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walden "Walden")_, was influenced by this movement.

The conflict surrounding [abolitionism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abolitionism_in_the_United_States "Abolitionism in the United States") inspired writers, like [Harriet Beecher Stowe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harriet_Beecher_Stowe "Harriet Beecher Stowe"), and authors of slave narratives, such as [Frederick Douglass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frederick_Douglass "Frederick Douglass"). [Nathaniel Hawthorne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nathaniel_Hawthorne "Nathaniel Hawthorne")'s _[The Scarlet Letter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Scarlet\_Letter "The Scarlet Letter")_ (1850) explored the dark side of American history, as did [Herman Melville](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herman_Melville "Herman Melville")'s _[Moby-Dick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moby-Dick "Moby-Dick")_ (1851). Major American poets of the 19th century [American Renaissance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Renaissance_(literature) "American Renaissance (literature)") include [Walt Whitman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walt_Whitman "Walt Whitman"), Melville, and [Emily Dickinson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emily_Dickinson "Emily Dickinson").[[539]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine2013444%E2%80%93447-562)[[540]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTELauter1994a1228,_1233,_1260-563)[Mark Twain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Twain "Mark Twain") was the first major American writer to be born in the West. [Henry James](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_James "Henry James") achieved international recognition with novels like _[The Portrait of a Lady](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Portrait\_of\_a\_Lady "The Portrait of a Lady")_ (1881). As literacy rates rose, periodicals published more stories centered around industrial workers, women, and the rural poor.[[541]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine20131269%E2%80%931270-564)[[542]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTELauter1994b8%E2%80%9310-565)[Naturalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naturalism_(literature) "Naturalism (literature)"), [regionalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_literary_regionalism "American literary regionalism"), and [realism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Literary_realism#UnitedStates "Literary realism") were the major literary movements of the period.[[543]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine20131271%E2%80%931273-566)[[544]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTELauter1994b12-567)

While [modernism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Literary_modernism "Literary modernism") generally took on an international character, modernist authors working within the United States more often rooted their work in specific regions, peoples, and cultures.[[545]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine20131850%E2%80%931851-568) Following the Great Migration to northern cities, African-American and black [West Indian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Indian_Americans "West Indian Americans") authors of the [Harlem Renaissance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harlem_Renaissance "Harlem Renaissance") developed an independent tradition of literature that rebuked a history of inequality and celebrated black culture. An important cultural export during the [Jazz Age](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jazz_Age "Jazz Age"), these writings were a key influence on _[NÃ©gritude](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/N%C3%A9gritude "NÃ©gritude")_, a philosophy emerging in the 1930s among francophone writers of the [African diaspora](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/African_diaspora "African diaspora").[[546]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-569)[[547]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-570) In the 1950s, an ideal of homogeneity led many authors to attempt to write the [Great American Novel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_American_Novel "Great American Novel"),[[548]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine20132260%E2%80%932261-571) while the [Beat Generation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beat_Generation "Beat Generation") rejected this conformity, using styles that elevated the impact of the [spoken word](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spoken_word "Spoken word") over mechanics to describe drug use, sexuality, and the failings of society.[[549]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine20132262-572)[[550]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-573) Contemporary literature is more pluralistic than in previous eras, with the closest thing to a unifying feature being a trend toward self-conscious [experiments with language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experimental_literature "Experimental literature").[[551]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine20132266%E2%80%932267-574) Twelve American laureates have won the [Nobel Prize in Literature](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature "Nobel Prize in Literature").[[552]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-575)

triples.sentence: [Mark Twain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Twain "Mark Twain"), whom [William Faulkner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Faulkner "William Faulkner") called "the father of American literature"[[531]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-faulkner-554)
triples.statement: William Faulkner called Mark Twain "the father of American literature".

triples.sentence: Colonial American authors were influenced by [John Locke](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Locke "John Locke") and other [Enlightenment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment "Age of Enlightenment") philosophers.[[532]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine2013157%E2%80%93159-555)[[533]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTELauter1994a503%E2%80%93509-556)
triples.statement: Authors in Colonial America were influenced by John Locke and other Enlightenment philosophers.

triples.sentence: Shortly before and after the [Revolutionary War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War "American Revolutionary War"), the newspaper rose to prominence, filling a demand for anti-British national literature.[[534]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine2013163-557)[[535]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-558)
triples.statement: Around the time of the Revolutionary War, newspapers became prominent by meeting a demand for anti-British national literature.

triples.sentence: Writer and critic [John Neal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Neal "John Neal") in the early- to mid-19th century helped advance America toward a unique literature and culture by criticizing predecessors such as [Washington Irving](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Irving "Washington Irving") for imitating their British counterparts, and by influencing writers such as [Edgar Allan Poe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edgar_Allan_Poe "Edgar Allan Poe"),[[536]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-559) who took American poetry and short fiction in new directions.
triples.statement: In the early- to mid-19th century, writer and critic John Neal helped develop a unique American literature by criticizing authors like Washington Irving for imitating British writers and by influencing authors like Edgar Allan Poe.

triples.sentence: [Ralph Waldo Emerson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ralph_Waldo_Emerson "Ralph Waldo Emerson") and [Margaret Fuller](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Margaret_Fuller "Margaret Fuller") pioneered the influential [Transcendentalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transcendentalism "Transcendentalism") movement;[[537]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-560)[[538]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Coviello-561)[Henry David Thoreau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_David_Thoreau "Henry David Thoreau"), author of _[Walden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walden "Walden")_, was influenced by this movement.
triples.statement: Ralph Waldo Emerson and Margaret Fuller were pioneers of the Transcendentalism movement, which influenced Henry David Thoreau, the author of Walden.

triples.sentence: Major American poets of the 19th century [American Renaissance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Renaissance_(literature) "American Renaissance (literature)") include [Walt Whitman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walt_Whitman "Walt Whitman"), Melville, and [Emily Dickinson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emily_Dickinson "Emily Dickinson").[[539]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine2013444%E2%80%93447-562)[[540]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTELauter1994a1228,_1233,_1260-563)
triples.statement: Prominent American poets of the 19th-century American Renaissance include Walt Whitman, Herman Melville, and Emily Dickinson.

triples.sentence: As literacy rates rose, periodicals published more stories centered around industrial workers, women, and the rural poor.[[541]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine20131269%E2%80%931270-564)[[542]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTELauter1994b8%E2%80%9310-565)
triples.statement: With rising literacy rates, periodicals began publishing more stories about industrial workers, women, and the rural poor.

triples.sentence: [Naturalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naturalism_(literature) "Naturalism (literature)"), [regionalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_literary_regionalism "American literary regionalism"), and [realism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Literary_realism#UnitedStates "Literary realism") were the major literary movements of the period.[[543]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine20131271%E2%80%931273-566)[[544]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTELauter1994b12-567)
triples.statement: Naturalism, regionalism, and realism were the primary literary movements of that time.

triples.sentence: While [modernism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Literary_modernism "Literary modernism") generally took on an international character, modernist authors working within the United States more often rooted their work in specific regions, peoples, and cultures.[[545]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine20131850%E2%80%931851-568)
triples.statement: Although modernism was typically international, modernist authors in the United States often based their work on specific regions, peoples, and cultures.

triples.sentence: An important cultural export during the [Jazz Age](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jazz_Age "Jazz Age"), these writings were a key influence on _[NÃ©gritude](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/N%C3%A9gritude "NÃ©gritude")_, a philosophy emerging in the 1930s among francophone writers of the [African diaspora](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/African_diaspora "African diaspora").[[546]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-569)[[547]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-570)
triples.statement: The writings from the Harlem Renaissance were a significant cultural export during the Jazz Age and a major influence on NÃ©gritude, a philosophy that developed in the 1930s among francophone writers of the African diaspora.

triples.sentence: In the 1950s, an ideal of homogeneity led many authors to attempt to write the [Great American Novel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_American_Novel "Great American Novel"),[[548]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine20132260%E2%80%932261-571) while the [Beat Generation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beat_Generation "Beat Generation") rejected this conformity, using styles that elevated the impact of the [spoken word](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spoken_word "Spoken word") over mechanics to describe drug use, sexuality, and the failings of society.[[549]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine20132262-572)[[550]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-573)
triples.statement: During the 1950s, a desire for homogeneity prompted many authors to try writing the Great American Novel, whereas the Beat Generation rejected this conformity, using styles that emphasized the spoken word to explore topics like drug use, sexuality, and societal flaws.

triples.sentence: Contemporary literature is more pluralistic than in previous eras, with the closest thing to a unifying feature being a trend toward self-conscious [experiments with language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experimental_literature "Experimental literature").[[551]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine20132266%E2%80%932267-574)
triples.statement: Contemporary literature is more pluralistic than in the past, with a trend toward self-conscious experiments with language being its most unifying feature.

section_body:
Main article: [Mass media in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_media_in_the_United_States "Mass media in the United States")

See also: [Newspapers in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newspapers_in_the_United_States "Newspapers in the United States"), [Television in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Television_in_the_United_States "Television in the United States"), [Broadcasting in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Broadcasting_in_the_United_States "Broadcasting in the United States"), [Public broadcasting in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_broadcasting_in_the_United_States "Public broadcasting in the United States"), [Internet in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_in_the_United_States "Internet in the United States"), [Radio in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio_in_the_United_States "Radio in the United States"), and [Video games in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_games_in_the_United_States "Video games in the United States")

[![Image 64](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Comcast_Center_2018.jpg/250px-Comcast_Center_2018.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Comcast_Center_2018.jpg)

[Comcast Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comcast_Center "Comcast Center") in [Philadelphia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia "Philadelphia"), headquarters of [Comcast](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comcast "Comcast"), one of the world's [largest telecommunications companies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_telecommunications_companies "List of telecommunications companies") and media conglomerates

Media in the United States is [broadly uncensored](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Censorship_in_the_United_States "Censorship in the United States"), with the [First Amendment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "First Amendment to the United States Constitution") providing significant protections, as reiterated in _[New York Times Co. v. United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New\_York\_Times\_Co.\_v.\_United\_States "New York Times Co. v. United States")_.[[511]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Coleman-2013-534) The four major broadcasters in the U.S. are the [National Broadcasting Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Broadcasting_Company "National Broadcasting Company") (NBC), [Columbia Broadcasting System](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Columbia_Broadcasting_System "Columbia Broadcasting System") (CBS), [American Broadcasting Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company "American Broadcasting Company") (ABC), and [Fox Broadcasting Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company "Fox Broadcasting Company") (FOX). The four major broadcast television networks are all commercial entities. The [U.S. cable television system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cable_television_in_the_United_States "Cable television in the United States") offers hundreds of channels catering to a variety of niches.[[553]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-576) In 2021, about 83% of Americans over age 12 listened to [broadcast radio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio_broadcasting "Radio broadcasting"), while about 40% listened to [podcasts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Podcast "Podcast").[[554]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-577) In the prior year, there were 15,460 licensed full-power radio stations in the U.S. according to the [Federal Communications Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Communications_Commission "Federal Communications Commission") (FCC).[[555]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-578) Much of the public radio broadcasting is supplied by [NPR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NPR "NPR"), incorporated in February 1970 under the [Public Broadcasting Act of 1967](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_Broadcasting_Act_of_1967 "Public Broadcasting Act of 1967").[[556]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-579)

U.S. newspapers with a global reach and reputation include _[The Wall Street Journal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Wall\_Street\_Journal "The Wall Street Journal")_, _[The New York Times](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_New\_York\_Times "The New York Times")_, _[The Washington Post](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Washington\_Post "The Washington Post")_, and _[USA Today](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USA\_Today "USA Today")_.[[557]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Shaffer2006-580)[About 800 publications](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Spanish-language_newspapers_published_in_the_United_States "List of Spanish-language newspapers published in the United States") are produced in Spanish.[[558]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-581)[[559]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-582) With few exceptions, newspapers are privately owned, either by large chains such as [Gannett](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gannett_Company "Gannett Company") or [McClatchy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_McClatchy_Company "The McClatchy Company"), which own dozens or even hundreds of newspapers; by small chains that own a handful of papers; or, in an increasingly rare situation, by individuals or families. Major cities often have [alternative newspapers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alternative_newspaper "Alternative newspaper") to complement the mainstream daily papers, such as _[The Village Voice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Village\_Voice "The Village Voice")_ in New York City and _[LA Weekly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LA\_Weekly "LA Weekly")_ in Los Angeles. The five most popular websites used in the U.S. are [Google](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Search "Google Search"), [YouTube](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/YouTube "YouTube"), [Facebook](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facebook "Facebook"), [Amazon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amazon_(website) "Amazon (website)"), and [Reddit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reddit "Reddit")â€”all of them American-owned.[[560]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-alexa-topsitesus-583)

In 2025, the U.S. was the world's [second-largest video game market by revenue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_video_games_markets_by_country "List of video games markets by country") (after China).[[561]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-584) In 2015, the U.S. video game industry consisted of 2,457 companies that employed around 220,000 jobs and generated $30.4 billion in revenue.[[562]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-:0-585) There are 444 game publishers, developers, and hardware companies in California alone.[[563]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-586) According to the [Game Developers Conference](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_Developers_Conference "Game Developers Conference") (GDC), the U.S. is the top location for [video game development](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_game_development "Video game development"), with 58% of the world's [game developers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_game_developer "Video game developer") based there in 2025.[[564]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-587)

triples.sentence: Media in the United States is [broadly uncensored](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Censorship_in_the_United_States "Censorship in the United States"), with the [First Amendment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "First Amendment to the United States Constitution") providing significant protections, as reiterated in _[New York Times Co. v. United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New\_York\_Times\_Co.\_v.\_United\_States "New York Times Co. v. United States")_.[[511]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Coleman-2013-534)
triples.statement: Media in the United States is broadly uncensored, with the First Amendment providing significant protections, as reiterated in the case of New York Times Co. v. United States.

triples.sentence: Much of the public radio broadcasting is supplied by [NPR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NPR "NPR"), incorporated in February 1970 under the [Public Broadcasting Act of 1967](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_Broadcasting_Act_of_1967 "Public Broadcasting Act of 1967").[[556]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-579)
triples.statement: Much of the public radio broadcasting is supplied by NPR, which was incorporated in February 1970 under the Public Broadcasting Act of 1967.

triples.sentence: U.S. newspapers with a global reach and reputation include _[The Wall Street Journal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Wall\_Street\_Journal "The Wall Street Journal")_, _[The New York Times](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_New\_York\_Times "The New York Times")_, _[The Washington Post](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Washington\_Post "The Washington Post")_, and _[USA Today](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USA\_Today "USA Today")_.[[557]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Shaffer2006-580)
triples.statement: U.S. newspapers with a global reach and reputation include The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times, The Washington Post, and USA Today.

triples.sentence: [About 800 publications](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Spanish-language_newspapers_published_in_the_United_States "List of Spanish-language newspapers published in the United States") are produced in Spanish.[[558]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-581)[[559]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-582)
triples.statement: About 800 publications are produced in Spanish.

section_body:
Main article: [Theater in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theater_in_the_United_States "Theater in the United States")

[![Image 65](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Various_Pictures_from_New_York_City_-_September%2C_2025.jpg/250px-Various_Pictures_from_New_York_City_-_September%2C_2025.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Various_Pictures_from_New_York_City_-_September,_2025.jpg)

[Broadway theaters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Broadway_theater "Broadway theater") in [Theater District, Manhattan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theater_District,_Manhattan "Theater District, Manhattan")

The United States is well known for its theater. Mainstream theater in the United States derives from the old European theatrical tradition and has been heavily influenced by the [British theater](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theatre_of_the_United_Kingdom "Theatre of the United Kingdom").[[565]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Saxon2011-588) By the middle of the 19th century, America had created new distinct dramatic forms in the [Tom Shows](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_Shows "Tom Shows"), the [showboat theater](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Showboat "Showboat") and the [minstrel show](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minstrel_show "Minstrel show").[[566]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-589) The central hub of the American theater scene is the [Theater District in Manhattan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theater_District,_Manhattan "Theater District, Manhattan"), with its divisions of [Broadway](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Broadway_theatre "Broadway theatre"), [off-Broadway](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Off-Broadway "Off-Broadway"), and [off-off-Broadway](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Off-off-Broadway "Off-off-Broadway").[[567]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Londr%C3%A9Watermeier1998-590)

Many movie and television [celebrities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Celebrity "Celebrity") have gotten their big break working in New York productions. Outside New York City, many cities have professional [regional or resident theater companies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regional_theater_in_the_United_States "Regional theater in the United States") that produce their own seasons. The biggest-budget theatrical productions are musicals. U.S. theater has an active [community theater](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Community_theater "Community theater") culture.[[568]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-591)

The [Tony Awards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Awards "Tony Awards") recognizes excellence in live Broadway theater and are presented at an annual ceremony in [Manhattan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manhattan "Manhattan"). The awards are given for Broadway productions and performances. One is also given for [regional theater](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regional_theatre_in_the_United_States "Regional theatre in the United States"). Several discretionary non-competitive awards are given as well, including a [Special Tony Award](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special_Tony_Award "Special Tony Award"), the [Tony Honors for Excellence in Theatre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Honors_for_Excellence_in_Theatre "Tony Honors for Excellence in Theatre"), and the [Isabelle Stevenson Award](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isabelle_Stevenson_Award "Isabelle Stevenson Award").[[569]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-592)

triples.sentence: Mainstream theater in the United States derives from the old European theatrical tradition and has been heavily influenced by the [British theater](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theatre_of_the_United_Kingdom "Theatre of the United Kingdom").[[565]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Saxon2011-588)
triples.statement: Mainstream theater in the United States derives from the old European theatrical tradition and has been heavily influenced by British theater.

triples.sentence: By the middle of the 19th century, America had created new distinct dramatic forms in the [Tom Shows](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_Shows "Tom Shows"), the [showboat theater](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Showboat "Showboat") and the [minstrel show](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minstrel_show "Minstrel show").[[566]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-589)
triples.statement: By the mid-19th century, America had created new distinct dramatic forms such as Tom Shows, showboat theater, and the minstrel show.

triples.sentence: U.S. theater has an active [community theater](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Community_theater "Community theater") culture.[[568]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-591)
triples.statement: U.S. theater has an active community theater culture.

section_body:
Main articles: [Visual art of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_art_of_the_United_States "Visual art of the United States") and [Architecture of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Architecture_of_the_United_States "Architecture of the United States")

[![Image 66](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Grant_Wood_-_American_Gothic_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/250px-Grant_Wood_-_American_Gothic_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Grant_Wood_-_American_Gothic_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg)

_[American Gothic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American\_Gothic "American Gothic")_ (1930) by [Grant Wood](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grant_Wood "Grant Wood") is one of the most famous [American paintings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_art_of_the_United_States "Visual art of the United States") and is widely [parodied](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parody "Parody").[[570]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-BBC-593)

[Folk art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Folk_art_of_the_United_States "Folk art of the United States") in [colonial America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colonial_america "Colonial america") grew out of artisanal [craftsmanship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Workmanship "Workmanship") in communities that allowed commonly trained people to individually express themselves. It was distinct from Europe's tradition of [high art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High_culture "High culture"), which was less accessible and generally less relevant to early American settlers.[[571]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-594) Cultural movements in art and craftsmanship in colonial America generally lagged behind those of Western Europe. For example, the prevailing medieval style of [woodworking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Woodworking "Woodworking") and primitive [sculpture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sculpture_of_the_United_States "Sculpture of the United States") became integral to early American folk art, despite the emergence of [Renaissance styles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renaissance_art "Renaissance art") in England in the late 16th and early 17th centuries. The new English styles would have been early enough to make a considerable impact on American folk art, but American styles and forms had already been firmly adopted. Not only did styles change slowly in early America, but there was a tendency for rural artisans there to continue their traditional forms longer than their urban counterparts didâ€”and far longer than those in Western Europe.[[511]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Coleman-2013-534)

The [Hudson River School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hudson_River_School "Hudson River School") was a mid-19th-century movement in the visual arts tradition of European [naturalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Realism_(arts) "Realism (arts)"). The 1913 [Armory Show](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Armory_Show "Armory Show") in New York City, an exhibition of European [modernist art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_art "Modern art"), shocked the public and transformed the U.S. art scene.[[572]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-595)

[American Realism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Realism "American Realism") and [American Regionalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Regionalism "American Regionalism") sought to reflect and give America new ways of looking at itself. [Georgia O'Keeffe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georgia_O%27Keeffe "Georgia O'Keeffe"), [Marsden Hartley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marsden_Hartley "Marsden Hartley"), and others experimented with new and individualistic styles, which would become known as [American modernism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_modernism "American modernism"). Major artistic movements such as the [abstract expressionism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abstract_expressionism "Abstract expressionism") of [Jackson Pollock](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jackson_Pollock "Jackson Pollock") and [Willem de Kooning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Willem_de_Kooning "Willem de Kooning") and the [pop art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pop_art "Pop art") of [Andy Warhol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Warhol "Andy Warhol") and [Roy Lichtenstein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roy_Lichtenstein "Roy Lichtenstein") developed largely in the United States. Major photographers include [Alfred Stieglitz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfred_Stieglitz "Alfred Stieglitz"), [Edward Steichen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Steichen "Edward Steichen"), [Dorothea Lange](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dorothea_Lange "Dorothea Lange"), [Edward Weston](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Weston "Edward Weston"), [James Van Der Zee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Van_Der_Zee "James Van Der Zee"), [Ansel Adams](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ansel_Adams "Ansel Adams"), and [Gordon Parks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Parks "Gordon Parks").[[573]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Davenport1991-596)

The tide of [modernism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modernism "Modernism") and then [postmodernism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Postmodernism "Postmodernism") has brought global fame to American architects, including [Frank Lloyd Wright](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Lloyd_Wright "Frank Lloyd Wright"), [Philip Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philip_Johnson "Philip Johnson"), and [Frank Gehry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Gehry "Frank Gehry").[[574]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-JansonJanson2003-597) The [Metropolitan Museum of Art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art "Metropolitan Museum of Art") in [Manhattan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manhattan "Manhattan") is the largest [art museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art_museum "Art museum") in the United States[[575]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-METLargestArtMuseum-598) and the [fourth-largest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_largest_art_museums "List of largest art museums") in the world.[[576]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-599)

triples.sentence: It was distinct from Europe's tradition of [high art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High_culture "High culture"), which was less accessible and generally less relevant to early American settlers.[[571]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-594)
triples.statement: American folk art was distinct from Europe's tradition of high art, which was less accessible and relevant to early American settlers.

triples.sentence: Not only did styles change slowly in early America, but there was a tendency for rural artisans there to continue their traditional forms longer than their urban counterparts didâ€”and far longer than those in Western Europe.[[511]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Coleman-2013-534)
triples.statement: In early America, styles changed slowly, and rural artisans tended to maintain traditional forms longer than their urban counterparts and much longer than those in Western Europe.

triples.sentence: Major photographers include [Alfred Stieglitz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfred_Stieglitz "Alfred Stieglitz"), [Edward Steichen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Steichen "Edward Steichen"), [Dorothea Lange](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dorothea_Lange "Dorothea Lange"), [Edward Weston](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Weston "Edward Weston"), [James Van Der Zee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Van_Der_Zee "James Van Der Zee"), [Ansel Adams](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ansel_Adams "Ansel Adams"), and [Gordon Parks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Parks "Gordon Parks").[[573]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Davenport1991-596)
triples.statement: Major American photographers include Alfred Stieglitz, Edward Steichen, Dorothea Lange, Edward Weston, James Van Der Zee, Ansel Adams, and Gordon Parks.

triples.sentence: The tide of [modernism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modernism "Modernism") and then [postmodernism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Postmodernism "Postmodernism") has brought global fame to American architects, including [Frank Lloyd Wright](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Lloyd_Wright "Frank Lloyd Wright"), [Philip Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philip_Johnson "Philip Johnson"), and [Frank Gehry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Gehry "Frank Gehry").[[574]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-JansonJanson2003-597)
triples.statement: The movements of modernism and postmodernism brought global fame to American architects like Frank Lloyd Wright, Philip Johnson, and Frank Gehry.

section_body:
Main article: [Music of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Music_of_the_United_States "Music of the United States")

[![Image 67](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Country_Music_Hall_of_Fame_2022a.jpg/250px-Country_Music_Hall_of_Fame_2022a.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Country_Music_Hall_of_Fame_2022a.jpg)

The [Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Country_Music_Hall_of_Fame_and_Museum "Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum") in [Nashville, Tennessee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nashville,_Tennessee "Nashville, Tennessee")
